And then also just as a matter of process, I just want to make sure that I'm correct here. When dealing with the FTC, so those 11 -- the proposal of those 11 facilities, you kind of have already gone to the first level of discussions and now it's, in a sense, being escalated to the 5 commissioners? I just want to make sure that, that step is correct.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me be clear or try to be clear. We have had multiple discussions over multiple months with the FTC and we are trying, to the best of our ability, to understand not just the nature of their concerns and the depth of their concerns and the bread
componenttext: Yes, so let me be clear or try to be clear. We have had multiple discussions over multiple months with the FTC and we are trying, to the best of our ability, to understand not just the nature of their concerns and the depth of their concerns and the breadth of their concerns, but also how we think we can remedy those concerns based upon our knowledge of this industry, based upon our knowledge of how to ship groceries to the customers and our knowledge of competitive positioning. So this package is a package that we have developed that we believe addresses their concern. We have received no approval from the FTC at any level on this package.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just, I guess, maybe you can't say so much at this point, but any further color on the specific markets where these 11 are located?
componenttext: Okay. And then just, I guess, maybe you can't say so much at this point, but any further color on the specific markets where these 11 are located?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we're really not going to get into talking about market share in individual markets.
componenttext: No, we're really not going to get into talking about market share in individual markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to Ajay Jain with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: We'll move on to Ajay Jain with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, Bill, based on your prepared comments on the merger and the objections by the FTC staff, I'm just wondering if your announcement with Performance Food could really set the stage for litigation with the FTC. So if the process goes in that directio
componenttext: I guess, Bill, based on your prepared comments on the merger and the objections by the FTC staff, I'm just wondering if your announcement with Performance Food could really set the stage for litigation with the FTC. So if the process goes in that direction, do you think you can wrap up any potential litigation and complete the merger process by the time the agreement is set to expire? I think that deadline is in September if I'm not mistaken. So do you feel like you're potentially running out of time to the extent that's an issue at all?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I want to make sure I'm answering this right. We think we have ample time, if we do end up in litigation, to work through that and still bring that to some type of closure before the expiration of the merger agreement. Is that what you're getting at?
componenttext: So I want to make sure I'm answering this right. We think we have ample time, if we do end up in litigation, to work through that and still bring that to some type of closure before the expiration of the merger agreement. Is that what you're getting at?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just finally, on the -- as a quick follow-up, on the merger-related expenses, can you just quantify a little bit better how much you expect that to moderate in the back half of the year?
componenttext: Okay. And just finally, on the -- as a quick follow-up, on the merger-related expenses, can you just quantify a little bit better how much you expect that to moderate in the back half of the year?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's -- I would love to be able to have a forecast for merger-related expenses. In certain of those line items, I can do that. I can say this consultant, were -- we don't need them anymore and these consultants, we still do. But a lot of that just depends
componenttext: It's -- I would love to be able to have a forecast for merger-related expenses. In certain of those line items, I can do that. I can say this consultant, were -- we don't need them anymore and these consultants, we still do. But a lot of that just depends on what we're doing in the fourth quarter and -- the third quarter and the fourth quarter of the year. So it is rather difficult to estimate those expenses on a go-forward basis. So I mean, to say they're moderating. They're certainly not going to go to 0. There's work that we're going to continue to do to prepare, but we're certainly looking to stand down any teams that have completed their work, so that we can reduce those expenses. And we look at that literally every month to cite how many consultants we need here supporting us, but it's too hard to call out, frankly, where we're going to be in the process and what work needs to be done.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next question will come from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just really quickly for me at this point. The overall trend of inflation kind of going forward, calendar '15. And if not calendar '15 at least, the back half of your fiscal '15 and just in terms of where you see it trending, and from a gross profit per ca
componenttext: Just really quickly for me at this point. The overall trend of inflation kind of going forward, calendar '15. And if not calendar '15 at least, the back half of your fiscal '15 and just in terms of where you see it trending, and from a gross profit per case perspective, if it's potentially kind of getting back into a place where passing on pricing can be easier to the customer in relation to a previous question.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're there yet, John. I do think we're beginning to see some subsiding in the trajectory of inflation rate. So hopefully, we've peaked here at the 6%. It's still early this quarter. The individual categories are moving around right now. The
componenttext: I don't think we're there yet, John. I do think we're beginning to see some subsiding in the trajectory of inflation rate. So hopefully, we've peaked here at the 6%. It's still early this quarter. The individual categories are moving around right now. The bulk of the inflation, as we see here today, is more on the meat side. Dairy is beginning to level out. So we don't make predictions or give guidance. But I -- you really asked 2 questions. I think the inflation over time, over the next 6, 9, 12 months should subside to some degree. I don't know where it ends up but, hopefully, less than the 5 to 6 because as we've always said, that's not good for our customers and that's why sometimes it's -- or actually most of the time, it's hard to pass those along as fast as you would like. So I think we're seeing a little relief, but too early to call until we get into March and April, and we're kind of back into the heavier volume months.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to Kelly Bania with BMO Capital.
componenttext: We'll move on to Kelly Bania with BMO Capital.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, just another one related to the merger. Just based on your discussions with the FTC over the last year and what their concerns are, I'm just curious how you would characterize what you perceive as the likelihood that the FTC will accept this prop
componenttext: I guess, just another one related to the merger. Just based on your discussions with the FTC over the last year and what their concerns are, I'm just curious how you would characterize what you perceive as the likelihood that the FTC will accept this proposal as a remedy. I mean, does this address all of their concerns in your point of view?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Appreciate the question. I don't think I'm in a position to really address the likelihood. There may be other people out there that can give you a better handle on that. I would just continue to say that we believe strongly in this merger. We believe it's
componenttext: Appreciate the question. I don't think I'm in a position to really address the likelihood. There may be other people out there that can give you a better handle on that. I would just continue to say that we believe strongly in this merger. We believe it's pro-competitive in what's already an incredibly competitive industry. We believe it's good for our customers. Clearly, there'll be some disruption, so I'm sure there's been some concerns conveyed to the FTC and to us from that standpoint. That's not unusual on mergers. We spend a year and tens of millions of dollars preparing the integration plan to mitigate as much disruption as possible. And we think, over the medium term to longer term, this is very good for our customer base. It's going to be good for our shareholders. We think it will actually raise the bar for competition in our industry, which, long term, is good for everybody in our industry. So we believe strongly in our case and that's probably all I can -- should and can comment on.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe another follow-up. How are these 11 DCs selected? Just doing some quick math, I think you also said [ph] about 80 DCs, and these look either like they're larger or more highly productive than the average. Just any comments there
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe another follow-up. How are these 11 DCs selected? Just doing some quick math, I think you also said [ph] about 80 DCs, and these look either like they're larger or more highly productive than the average. Just any comments there would be helpful.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to start and Chris can give you probably a little more -- essentially, I think you can see it. If you put together all the color we're trying to provide today, we try to put together a footprint that would address the western part of the Un
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to start and Chris can give you probably a little more -- essentially, I think you can see it. If you put together all the color we're trying to provide today, we try to put together a footprint that would address the western part of the United States in a way that would complement the current footprint that PFG has, which is across the country, but it's a little less dense in the West compared to U.S. So what you're seeing there primarily is an attempt both with large and medium-sized facilities to address that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll move on to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So one of the challenges on the divestitures is, is there any way to guarantee that the customers really follow the facility divestitures? And I wonder if there's any way you could give us, from a big picture standpoint, what the market share on the natio
componenttext: So one of the challenges on the divestitures is, is there any way to guarantee that the customers really follow the facility divestitures? And I wonder if there's any way you could give us, from a big picture standpoint, what the market share on the national account looks like before and after the divestitures.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's no way to guarantee it. But again, we've done a lot of work on the integration planning and working through this TSA agreement with PFG to address that. And Chris has been leading that work, so I'll let him take that.
componenttext: Well, there's no way to guarantee it. But again, we've done a lot of work on the integration planning and working through this TSA agreement with PFG to address that. And Chris has been leading that work, so I'll let him take that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, one of the things, as I said in our integration planning, one of our primary principles was the least amount of disruption to our customers, US Foods' customers. We took the same approach in our discussions with PFG, and obviously, they care
componenttext: Yes, I mean, one of the things, as I said in our integration planning, one of our primary principles was the least amount of disruption to our customers, US Foods' customers. We took the same approach in our discussions with PFG, and obviously, they care a lot about that as well. And so we've structured it in a way that we believe is going to be least disruptive to those customers. So if you think about a customer that's being serviced out of the, call it, Denver facility for US Foods today, that same salesperson, those same trucks, food coming out of that same facility is going to go to that customer once it is owned by PFG. So we believe that's the least amount of disruption to the customer. And as long as they continue to get good service at fair prices and value, we don't believe there's a reason for them to want to change. So I'll agree with Bill, there's no guarantee, but I believe we've set this up in a way that the customers will continue to get good service and good value going forward.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are there long-term contracts that transfer? And is there a noncompete agreement or anything like that on going after those customers?
componenttext: Are there long-term contracts that transfer? And is there a noncompete agreement or anything like that on going after those customers?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a lot of things that will be contained in the 8-K, which we'll file later this [indiscernible], so I'd encourage you to look into that. There's enough in there, I think, to keep you busy for a while. But as you might imagine, we intend to, an
componenttext: Yes, there's a lot of things that will be contained in the 8-K, which we'll file later this [indiscernible], so I'd encourage you to look into that. There's enough in there, I think, to keep you busy for a while. But as you might imagine, we intend to, and the FTC, of course, would want us to set PFG up for success here and again -- and do it in a way that our customers don't feel or experience that disruption. So everything that's necessary to make that happen, we've put into the TSA or the agreement.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think just to illustrate that from maybe -- from for a layman's standpoint, what Chris and Russell and our teams have done is basically, as you look at -- don't just look at it as facilities. From a customer's perspective, they're going to be positioned
componenttext: I think just to illustrate that from maybe -- from for a layman's standpoint, what Chris and Russell and our teams have done is basically, as you look at -- don't just look at it as facilities. From a customer's perspective, they're going to be positioned at the same salesperson, the same driver, the same customer service team in this TSA agreement, which you can look at once we get it out in the K, 8-K. We've taken a lot of measures to position PFG to be successful as they transition that business. So we've done a lot of things to position them for success. Early days here.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I know you've addressed this, the $600 million synergy number, but you stand back and look at the deal from a broad perspective, US Foods has lost earnings power while it's been waiting for the transaction to close. If you look at where they are
componenttext: Okay. And I know you've addressed this, the $600 million synergy number, but you stand back and look at the deal from a broad perspective, US Foods has lost earnings power while it's been waiting for the transaction to close. If you look at where they are today, add in the synergies, where do you think you'll be on EPS accretion by year 4 or 5?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've not given and I'm probably not going to today, given any kind of forecast for earnings accretion. We obviously have relooked at the transaction based upon everything that's happened over the year and based upon this divestiture package, and we still
componenttext: We've not given and I'm probably not going to today, given any kind of forecast for earnings accretion. We obviously have relooked at the transaction based upon everything that's happened over the year and based upon this divestiture package, and we still feel this is a very, very nice return for Sysco and our shareholders. We've got to, obviously, get the deal closed, and then we've got to work on executing against the synergies. And we now also -- and there'd a little more -- add a little more complexity. We also need to work on the divestiture package to make sure that, that's set up all right. As long as we continue to service the customers, ours and US Foods, we get a very nice return out of the transaction, and that's what we're focused on.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And ladies and gentlemen, we have no further questions at this time. That does conclude today's conference. We do thank you for your participation. Have a good day.
componenttext: And ladies and gentlemen, we have no further questions at this time. That does conclude today's conference. We do thank you for your participation. Have a good day.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Audio Gap]in deploying SAP and all of the standardized processes it requires. Over the past 2 years under Wayne's leadership, we've refined our business processes, strengthened our technology support capabilities, stabilized the SAP system and enhanced
componenttext:
[Audio Gap]
in deploying SAP and all of the standardized processes it requires. Over the past 2 years under Wayne's leadership, we've refined our business processes, strengthened our technology support capabilities, stabilized the SAP system and enhanced its efficiency. While there's more work to be done, we are well positioned to move forward with a cohesive, enterprise-wide, modular-centric approach rather than our previous OpCo-by-OpCo multimodule approach. As our deployment process matures and evolves in the future, we expect this change to result in smoother conversions, better execution and an improved experience for our customers. 
On the acquisition front, we recently completed the previously announced agreement to acquire 50% of Pacific Star Foodservice, a leading foodservice distributor in México. We have developed a strong relationship over the past several years with the ownership and management team of Pacific Star, and we're very excited about the potential opportunities that this partnership will provide to profitably grow our business in Mexico. 
Regarding our pending merger with U.S. Foods, the hearing related to the FTC's motion for preliminary injunction begins tomorrow, May 5, and will last up to 7 business days. If we receive a ruling on our favor, we will proceed with closing unless the decision is appealed. In the event of an unfavorable ruling, we would assess together with U.S. Foods ownership whether to pursue the case further. We remain resolute in our belief that this transaction is procompetitive, good for our customers and will accelerate Sysco's business transformation. 
We announced in April that Joe has been named Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer effective September 1, 2015, following Chris Kreidler's decision to leave the company. Joe is a veteran Sysco leader with nearly 20 years of experience in key finance and commercial roles. He is uniquely suited to step into the CFO position because of his deep knowledge of our local operations and people. We are fortunate to have a leader like Joe already to take on this key position, and I look forward to working closely with him in his new role as we move forward. 
We appreciate the numerous important contributions Chris has made on Sysco's behalf since joining us 5 years ago. He has agreed to remain as CFO through August, and he will work closely with Joe and Sysco Senior Executive team to ensure an orderly transition of his responsibilities, including staying on through the end of December as an adviser. 
In closing, I am pleased with the consistent case growth we've seen in our locally managed and corporate managed business, which demonstrates our associates' unwavering focus on providing consistent and excellent service to our customers. In addition, our leadership team is making good progress in driving our initiatives to enhance both gross profit dollar growth and expense management. Our ongoing work to fundamentally reshape our company is challenging but gratifying, and we strongly believe that the steps we are taking will reinforce our leadership position in the ever evolving foodservice industry. 
Now I'll turn things over to Chris so he can provide additional details on our financial results for the third quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, sales were $11.7 billion, an increase of 4.2% compared to the prior year. Our sales growth rate was substantially lower than the 7% rate we saw during the first half of the fiscal year becau
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, sales were $11.7 billion, an increase of 4.2% compared to the prior year. Our sales growth rate was substantially lower than the 7% rate we saw during the first half of the fiscal year because of the rapid decline in food cost inflation and the impact of foreign exchange translation. Food cost inflation declined significantly from 6% in the second quarter to 3.7% in the third quarter. Our estimates for food cost inflation represents the weighted average change in Sysco's cost for the same products year-over-year. At 3.7%, it would appear we are getting close to what we normally describe as the sweet spot for inflation of 2% to 3%, but the 3.7% is an average across all of our product lines and sometimes averages don't tell the whole story as is the case here. Specifically, the meat category experienced low double-digit inflation in the quarter, and poultry inflation was in the high single digits. On a weighted-average basis, these 2 categories accounted for 3.2% of the 3.7% inflation we experienced across all of our categories. At these levels, passing along all of the inflation can be painful for our customers putting gross margin under pressure. In addition, rapid declines in food cost also make it challenging to leverage our fixed cost. 
The impact of changes in foreign exchange rates had a much larger impact than usual this quarter. Similar to many companies with significant operations outside of the U.S., the strengthening dollar depressed our foreign sales as we converted them to U.S. dollars. This quarter's decrease of 1.3% was the highest in the past 3 years. The impact has typically been in the range of 0 to 0.5%. 
Sales from acquisitions increased sales by 0.6%. Case volume grew 2.5% during the quarter, including acquisitions and approximately 2.2% excluding acquisitions. Gross profit in the third quarter was $2.1 billion, a 3.1% increase, while gross margin declined 17 basis points to 17.52%. Benefits from category management contributed significantly to our gross profit during the quarter. In addition, case volume growth for our locally managed Broadline business continued to increase slightly on a sequential basis as it has done the last 2 quarters. Solid local case growth is important to drive gross profit dollar growth. Case growth for our corporate managed customers remained strong, but competitive pricing pressure in this segment contributed to gross margin pressure. Certain items for the third quarter totaled $91 million and related to merger and integration planning expenses and interest on the merger of debt. Of this amount, $50 million was recorded an operating expense and $41 million was recorded in interest expense. 
Merger and integration planning cost that impacted operating expenses were mainly related to work to prepare for the integration of the 2 companies' technology platforms. These expenses in total were lower than in the third quarter compared to levels in the first half of the year as we scaled back our integration planning work in certain areas where a significant amount of work has already been completed. Merger cost that impacted interest expense relates to the debt that we issued last October that is intended to refinance US Foods' debt upon closing of the transaction. We are treating this interest expense as a certain item until the merger closes. 
Adjusted operating expenses for the third quarter increased $73 million or 4.5% due to $61 million increase in payroll expense. Payroll expense increased mainly due to higher pay for our sales organization as a result of higher gross profit, investments in new administrative support capabilities, higher incentive accruals and newly-acquired operations. These increases were partially offset by lower delivery costs, mainly driven by savings and fuel expense. After excluding incentives, adjusted operating expenses would have increased 3.9%. 
Our cost per case performance improved modestly from earlier in the year, but as Bill mentioned, expense management remain a challenge for us. Adjusted cost per case performance for the third quarter in the North American Broadline business, which is the portion of the business we've given guidance on previously, increased only $0.03 in the third quarter. However, excluding the benefit from currency translation, cost per case would have increased by $0.09. We have previously said we expect cost per case to increase between $0.05 and $0.10 this year. We would expect to be on the low end of this range, including the impact of foreign exchange and on the high end of this range, excluding foreign exchange. We are focused on driving improvements across our operations with multiple initiatives that implement best practices, enhance our operating training programs and improve our ability to measure and analyze our performance. 
Adjusted operating income from the quarter was $377 million, down 2.7% from the prior year, and adjusted operating margin was 3.2%, down 23 basis points from last year. Our effective tax rate in the third quarter was 34% compared to 39% in the prior year period. This quarter's rate was positively impacted by the favorable resolution of estate tax matter. In the prior year, the rate was elevated due to the nondeductible portion of a $20 million legal settlement that we disclosed at the time. Normalizing for these types of discrete events, our tax rate would be roughly 37%. This is lower than our historical rates due to the increasing amount of business earnings and international jurisdictions that have lower tax rates as well as reduced state taxes from legal restructurings. 
Adjusted net earnings increased 7% to $238 million, and adjusted EPS increased 5.3% to $0.40. Cash flow performance in the first 39 weeks of the year was relatively strong after taking into account the cash impact of certain items. Cash flow from operations increased $12 million to $860 million versus last year. This increase reflects the negative impact of 2 items. First, the cash impact of certain items increased $82 million year-over-year mainly due to merger and integration planning expenses. Second, as we disclosed earlier this year, we made a $50 million pension contribution this year compared to none in the prior year period. This difference is simply driven by a different timing regarding when we make cash contributions each year. Cash tax payments were $135 million lower than last year due to a lower effective tax rate, which I discussed a moment ago and merger and integration planning expenses that reduced taxable earnings. Free cash flow was $439 million in the first 39 weeks of fiscal 2015 compared to $484 million in the prior year period or a reduction of $46 million. However, after adjusting for the cash impact of certain items and the increase in pension contribution I mentioned a moment ago, free cash flow was $617 [ph] million, an increase of $86 million or 16% from the prior year period. Capital expenditures for the first 39 weeks of the year, net of proceeds from sale of assets, increased $58 million to $422 million. About $53 million of this increase is due to IT-related merger integration planning and the rest was due to timing of investments in our fleet. 
Our cash flow from operations and free cash flow are always impacted by foreign currency translation, but the impact of the first of 39 weeks of fiscal 2015 is much greater than the last few years. You will see in the cash flow statement a $77 million impact this year compared to less than $0.5 million last year. This means our cash flows would have been $77 million higher on a constant dollar basis. 
Turning to an update on recent acquisitions. On last month, we completed the previously announced transaction to buy 50% of Pacific Star Foodservice, a leading foodservice distributor in Mexico. Pacific Star is operated since 1989 with distribution centers servicing customers in the major Metropolitan areas of Mexico City, Guadalajara, Monterrey and Tijuana. It primarily services chain accounts, including fast food and casual dining restaurants, casinos, theme parks, movie theaters and hotels throughout Mexico. This partnership fits our international expansion strategy, allows us to enhance service to our U.S. customers who operate in the region and provides growth opportunities in an important region of the Americas. In addition, subsequent to the end of the quarter, we announced our agreement to acquire Tannis Trading in Canada. Tannis operates in the Ottawa market, the fourth largest in Canada. This acquisition, which remain subject to regulatory approval, would allow us to better serve our customers and achieve our goal of increasing sales in Canada. 
Regarding our outlook for the remainder of the year, there are a few additional items I'd like to point out. First, as we discussed last quarter, because of the pending merger during this fiscal year, we have not been in the market buying back shares to offset dilution from incentive-based compensation as we would normally be doing. This has had the effect of increasing our shares outstanding in the first 39 weeks of the fiscal year due to the exercise of employee stock options and divesting of restricted stock units. As a result, both adjusted and reported diluted EPS were lower by $0.005 in the third quarter and $0.015 [ph] over the first 39 weeks.  Unless we repurchased shares during the fourth quarter, we estimate that our diluted shares outstanding maybe greater than 597 million shares in the fiscal year. This estimate is dependent on the level of stock option exercises and issued investing occurs and does not include shares issued in conjunction with the pending US Foods merger. Second, please note that we plan to pay off $300 million in bonds that come due in mid-June. We currently anticipate using cash on hand to fund this payment. 
Lastly, our forecast for capital expenditures, net of proceeds from asset sales, remains at $500 million -- sorry, $500 million to $550 million for fiscal year 2015, but we now expect to be at the high end of this range for the year. In closing, while our top line has been negatively impacted by lower levels of inflation and the larger impact from foreign currency translation, we are pleased that the business continues to generate solid case volume growth, in particular, in the locally managed portion of our business. We have opportunities to improve our operating expense management and have begun to make some progress in this area. But importantly, the business continues to generate strong free cash flow. While we have work ahead of us to transform the business, there are many exciting initiatives underway that will enhance our customers' experience, strengthen our operating performance and increase profitability. 
With that, operator, we'll now take some questions.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from John Heinbockel with the Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from John Heinbockel with the Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually a technical question and strategic one. So Bill, on the technical side, it would seem that inflation probably moderates a bit further than here. Can you offset that with cost reduction? Or is the uncertainty around US Foods kind of where the busi
componenttext: Actually a technical question and strategic one. So Bill, on the technical side, it would seem that inflation probably moderates a bit further than here. Can you offset that with cost reduction? Or is the uncertainty around US Foods kind of where the business is today hamstring you from doing that? And then I have a strategic one.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, we have to. I mean so, yes, I do think in the past we've been able to adjust our expenses accordingly, and I agree with your premise. I think you could see the inflation come down a little bit more just for the reasons Chris -- so we got a couple of
componenttext: John, we have to. I mean so, yes, I do think in the past we've been able to adjust our expenses accordingly, and I agree with your premise. I think you could see the inflation come down a little bit more just for the reasons Chris -- so we got a couple of categories that are pretty high. The others -- you got dairy is very volatile, as you know, so dairy is down a little bit. Seafood is down a little bit, but Seafood is not a big part of the overall mix. So I think essentially, you're looking at an environment today where you've got 2 categories, meat and poultry that are high, which is difficult to pass along in a fast way and the right way. And the others are pretty much neutral if you put them all together. And yes, I expect that to continue here at least for, whatever, a few, couple, 3 months as far as we can see out. As I said in my comments, we are seeing improvement on the expensive sequentially. We're not just seeing as fast as we have planned, and I think you will see more expense improvement here in the fourth quarter relative to the first part of the year and we're certainly planning to do even more for next year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then strategically, I don't want to how to talk about this, but have you done much planning if US Foods doesn't happen? And what would you do differently than you're doing today if that doesn't come to fruition?
componenttext: And then strategically, I don't want to how to talk about this, but have you done much planning if US Foods doesn't happen? And what would you do differently than you're doing today if that doesn't come to fruition?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, one of the things I feel pretty good about is we've been a nice job here. We spent some money doing it, separating running the business day to day and keeping our people, the vast majority of our people focused on taking care of their
componenttext: Well, first of all, one of the things I feel pretty good about is we've been a nice job here. We spent some money doing it, separating running the business day to day and keeping our people, the vast majority of our people focused on taking care of their customers and running their business and not having to be distracted by the merger. And as we have another group of people, outside support folks who've done a great job under Chris and Greg leadership driving very sound integration plan. So I feel good about what we've done to date. Yes, we've done some contingent planning, and it's not fully developed. We've had discussions of the management team and with our board, and we'll continue to have those discussions. And once we have a ruling, then we'll probably take some more time but not a lot of time and go forth from there with some other strategic directions. But so, yes, we've done some planning, but not in a position today to really talk a lot about that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank. And we'll move on to Edward Kelly with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank. And we'll move on to Edward Kelly with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just have a -- I actually have a follow-up to John's question here. Bill, in the past, you guys have mentioned international M&A as an area of interest. I mean obviously, the U.S. market is top-of-mind right now, but if material consolidation is not pos
componenttext: I just have a -- I actually have a follow-up to John's question here. Bill, in the past, you guys have mentioned international M&A as an area of interest. I mean obviously, the U.S. market is top-of-mind right now, but if material consolidation is not possible here, where are your heads today actually relative to where we were in the past? Is it something that you'd be interested in?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly. As you heard, we're pleased with the joint venture that we just finalized with our partners down in Mexico. And we've gradually built out some small footprint in Costa Rica and now Mexico, Bahamas, Ireland. Canada was the first one obviously. S
componenttext: Certainly. As you heard, we're pleased with the joint venture that we just finalized with our partners down in Mexico. And we've gradually built out some small footprint in Costa Rica and now Mexico, Bahamas, Ireland. Canada was the first one obviously. So I think where we are thereat is just a matter of place to place. And we definitely -- and we talked about the strategy of the company. The fifth point we talk about is always looking for other areas to expand whether through adjacencies or through geographics. And I just see it more as something we need to do continually. And over the next 3 or 5 years, I would like to think that we'll continue to find good partners in different parts of the world where our customers value our capabilities and find ways to grow there, primarily to lay a foundation for the future beyond that. So I see international more is something we need to do. We need to continually build it for the medium to long term. Short to medium term, obviously, US Foods is a big, big part of our strategy. It's not our strategy. It's a big part of the strategy. If that's not the workout, we would revisit other strategic opportunities that we looked at in the past and look our capital structure, all those types of things. Just not in a position today to talk a whole a lot about that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Bill, when you think about the U.S. business now, there's obviously always puts and takes and what impact the earnings. I mean the backdrop doesn't really seem to be too bad right now with what's going on with restaurant sales and lower fuel. But this
componenttext: And Bill, when you think about the U.S. business now, there's obviously always puts and takes and what impact the earnings. I mean the backdrop doesn't really seem to be too bad right now with what's going on with restaurant sales and lower fuel. But this quarter, you're back to EBITDA actually being down a little bit year-over-year after a couple of quarters good growth. And I guess, the question is, what it's really saying about the outlook for the business, I guess, absent the deal? And you touched on it a little bit, but is there a need for some larger strategic refresh or restructuring if the transaction were not to happen? Or are you really just -- is it really more about fine-tuning?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think both, all right. So we need to manage what we have the ability to control the most, which is our business, and we're pretty good at running our business. Obviously, as we've said for a while now, the market environment we're in is difficult. It's
componenttext: I think both, all right. So we need to manage what we have the ability to control the most, which is our business, and we're pretty good at running our business. Obviously, as we've said for a while now, the market environment we're in is difficult. It's very competitive, and it's not like many other industries and we don't expect that to change. So again, to kind of recap how we look at the world, we see modest medium- to long-term growth in the industry. We expect to grow faster than that. To do that, we need to differentiate ourselves ongoing-ly with our customers and we need to take cost out of the system. It's one of the reasons why this merger is so important to us. If the merger doesn't happen, we'll need to find other ways to continue to do that. We may not get there quite as fast, but I'm confident we'll continue to go in the right direction. Specifically, to this quarter, you can look at it a lot of different ways. The bottom line is we didn't manage our expenses as well as we would have liked. If we had manage our cost may be just $0.05 better, I think you would have seen the different result here, and I would haven't talked as much about planned expenses. So we're going to have quarters where there's inflation and less inflation. We had good volume growth, as I said. We managed gross profit reasonably well given the environment. We just didn't bring our expenses and as well as weed plan, and we expect to be a little bit better over the next 2 or 3 quarters.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry about before. Just curious, I mean, I know we've talked a lot about the expense issue, and I guess I'm still confused as to why it's been a problem now for 2 quarters in a row. I mean, I know you pointed to some things in terms of comps that affecte
componenttext: Sorry about before. Just curious, I mean, I know we've talked a lot about the expense issue, and I guess I'm still confused as to why it's been a problem now for 2 quarters in a row. I mean, I know you pointed to some things in terms of comps that affected the expenses, but anything else you can kind of put some color on?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll do my best, Karen. I would say this quarter is a little different in that our selling expense was higher than it was in the first half of the year. We were up couple of pennies the first year in selling. That was fine. We had a lot of gross profit do
componenttext: I'll do my best, Karen. I would say this quarter is a little different in that our selling expense was higher than it was in the first half of the year. We were up couple of pennies the first year in selling. That was fine. We had a lot of gross profit dollar growth, and that's going to drive selling expense. So this quarter is up more than that. It's still probably fine, but it just can't be sustained. I mean, it's just -- we just have a situation where seasonally, it's a low-volume quarter. It's also the time that we bring MAs on in terms of training. And we have some operating companies that were behind in our headcount, and I think that put some pressure on us here as well. So selling cost is a little higher than what we plan. On the operations side, we're making progress. We're driving out a lot of change here, Karen. And we've been driving out very aggressively over the last year, 2 years, and that put a lot of stress on the operating companies at a time when they still need to provide really solid service to our customers. And so there's been some challenges in terms of how fast you can drive that change and how well it's received by our workforce and how well our leadership, including me are able to drive that out. So what we're doing here is transforming the company and we're bringing more standardization to our best practices in the field. We're functionalizing that part of our business in terms of the OpCo and our supply chain organization now, and it's just taking a little longer to get where we want to go. The good news is we are seeing sequential growth and improvement, and that's what gives me some confidence here.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Karen, this is Chris. I'll jump in n just elaborate on 1 point Bill made. Remember, a couple of years ago, we talked about the changes we made in our sales organization and we saw that disruption. We saw that disruption and slowed growth in terms of case
componenttext: Karen, this is Chris. I'll jump in n just elaborate on 1 point Bill made. Remember, a couple of years ago, we talked about the changes we made in our sales organization and we saw that disruption. We saw that disruption and slowed growth in terms of case volume on the local side especially, and we talk quite a bit about it at the time. We pushed a lot of change, and it took a while for all that change to kind of be accepted and understood and appropriately reacted to in the field. I think what you're seeing now is somewhat similar going on the operating expense environment. We are, as Bill said, pushing a lot of change. It's for the good. It's can lead to better results in the future, but it's going to take a while for some of that change actually to drive all the way down to the operating company level. And I think that's part of what we're experiencing right now. Not an excuse. We need to manage it better, but I do think we're seeing some of that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I mean to your point on MAs and progress on the top line, I get independent sales definitely seem fairly strong although SYGMA was weak. But anything that point to on what was driving the strength in independent?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I mean to your point on MAs and progress on the top line, I get independent sales definitely seem fairly strong although SYGMA was weak. But anything that point to on what was driving the strength in independent?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's the good news. When we talk about initiatives, there are now about cost savings and I think what you're seeing there is some several things that we've done over the last 2 or 3 years starting with a CRM tool, category management, we'r
componenttext: Well, I think that's the good news. When we talk about initiatives, there are now about cost savings and I think what you're seeing there is some several things that we've done over the last 2 or 3 years starting with a CRM tool, category management, we're getting better executing that. Some basic things we're doing in terms of working with our MAs and training and how to segment more effectively our customers and product categories and just creating more continuity between the corporate sales organization and the field sales organization as well as the OpCos overall. So we're pleased both on the local side and the corporate side. If you go back 4, 5 quarters, we had no growth on the local side. So I think that is a bright spot, and that is certainly is something we've emphasized and something we needed to continue to emphasize.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Again just last question on the expense side. What's driving the merger and integration increase? Because I guess I was under the impression that you kind of completed all you could from a merger and integration expense perspective until you know more or
componenttext: Again just last question on the expense side. What's driving the merger and integration increase? Because I guess I was under the impression that you kind of completed all you could from a merger and integration expense perspective until you know more or until hopefully you close the merger, and it still seem to be -- I mean, it's still increasing.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's actually not increasing. On a sequential basis, it's starting to decline. We had a peak last quarter, Karen. It's coming down from there. But I'll take your question to where I think you want to go anyway, why is it not perhaps dropping faster.
componenttext: Well, it's actually not increasing. On a sequential basis, it's starting to decline. We had a peak last quarter, Karen. It's coming down from there. But I'll take your question to where I think you want to go anyway, why is it not perhaps dropping faster. There are couple of reasons. I mean the interest portion of that obviously is not going to go anywhere, but even on the operating expense portion, there's a lot of work that continues to be done to prepare the 2 IT systems to be able to merge. We're not touching the U.S. food system or vice versa, but we're creating the conduits that will be necessary to allow them to merge. Unfortunately, at this deal has dragged out, we were able to stand down certain aspects of what we're doing from a planning perspective as we can stand them back rather quickly. But in a lot of other areas, we need all the time we could possibly get to be prepared for merger and integrating and we continue some of that work. So it's come down somewhat. I expect it to not increase again, of course, until we complete the transaction and, of course, we'll be giving you guidance.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Meredith Adler from Barclays.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Meredith Adler from Barclays.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk a little bit about cash. I've spent many years in fixed income land and cash is cash. You can't really define it, and it just looks to me like in fact, you're not covering your dividend or didn't for the first time onto the year. And then
componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about cash. I've spent many years in fixed income land and cash is cash. You can't really define it, and it just looks to me like in fact, you're not covering your dividend or didn't for the first time onto the year. And then so I'm wondering you have a $300 million payment you're going to make this year. Could you talk about, are you going to borrow? Do have a revolving credit facility that you're going to borrow under? And if sort of the same thing holds true, if the deal does not go through, you probably will have your bonds will be put back to you, the $5 billion, but you're not sitting on that much cash. So what do you think happens? How do you find that put if it happens?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take that, the 2 pieces of that, First, the $300 million, as I mentioned, we will pay that out of the cash that we have sitting on the balance sheet, which is just shy of $5 billion. That's what we'll do initially. If we then repay the bond be
componenttext: Yes, let me take that, the 2 pieces of that, First, the $300 million, as I mentioned, we will pay that out of the cash that we have sitting on the balance sheet, which is just shy of $5 billion. That's what we'll do initially. If we then repay the bond because you correctly pointed out if the merger agreement terminates, there is a process for those to be redeemed, we would pay those back out whatever we can pay out of cash, we would put into our credit facility. We do have a very large commercial paper line backstop buyer credit facility by $1.5 billion, so we've got plenty of capacity still on the balance sheet. We would then look at whether we have enough capacity for just general working capital needs and we've looked at whether we need to trim out some of the debt that we've taken on the balance sheet the last couple of years the acquisitions we've done, et cetera. We would do that after that point in time when things settle out.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other question. You said that -- sorry?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other question. You said that -- sorry?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the cash point, I would just -- going back to the earlier questions we had, first of all, we're going to have our dividend. If you adjust for the merger-related expenses and things like that, we're going to more than cover our dividend from free c
componenttext: Just on the cash point, I would just -- going back to the earlier questions we had, first of all, we're going to have our dividend. If you adjust for the merger-related expenses and things like that, we're going to more than cover our dividend from free cash flow this year. And second of all, when I look at cash is strategically, we include that capacity. So obviously, as you all know, we're very highly rated company from a debt perspective. We have plenty of debt capacity, and certainly, we want to utilize it prudently, but I'm very confident in our ability to fund whatever we need to fund.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not actually worried about liquidity. You're not going to run out of liquidity. My next question, just quickly, is about category management and cycling the improvements you've seen so far. I think the real cycle summoned this next quarter, but it sou
componenttext: I'm not actually worried about liquidity. You're not going to run out of liquidity. My next question, just quickly, is about category management and cycling the improvements you've seen so far. I think the real cycle summoned this next quarter, but it sounded like to have more coming. How do you think that balances out in terms of the benefit of the gross margin?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you're right. We'll finish up the third year, and we said capital management is somewhat back-end loaded. We've seen those benefits this year. I think the key -- the way I look at that, Meredith, it's just we're now maturing to a point where, while
componenttext: Well, you're right. We'll finish up the third year, and we said capital management is somewhat back-end loaded. We've seen those benefits this year. I think the key -- the way I look at that, Meredith, it's just we're now maturing to a point where, while we speak about category management, it's truly is embedded in how we merchandise and we have centralized merchandising here to a large extent. We certainly standardize all of it. We still do some locally in terms of working with suppliers. But for the most part, we're working with the suppliers here at corporate and then working closely with our operating companies. So from that standpoint, we realize a lot of benefits, but that's some more launches here today later this year into next year, not a significant part of the overall volume. And then I think what you'll see us do is we'll get into renewals, and we'll continue to perfect what we started here and get better at it and probably have more time to focus on innovation side, which is critical obviously to growing the business as well. So I look at it as something which we will continue to get better at which would continue to help us mitigate the overall margin pressure that we face in the business itself. But something that we feel really good about the this point.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Andrew Wolf from BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Andrew Wolf from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, I wanted to ask you about the sales trends during the quarter into April and was pretty abrupt from quite strong the kind of weak. And I didn't see Sysco's number but for the industry, sounded like you guys are outperformed that. But what you think
componenttext: Bill, I wanted to ask you about the sales trends during the quarter into April and was pretty abrupt from quite strong the kind of weak. And I didn't see Sysco's number but for the industry, sounded like you guys are outperformed that. But what you think is going on in the industry? I mean, you kind of alluded to weather because last year was easy and this March was tough. What you think is going on in April? I mean, do have some insight into things may be stabilizing or turning back up here in later part of April, early May?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Andy, as you noticed, I didn't really talk about the industry and the market because it's hard to make that call right now. While I did talk about weather, I didn't find about weather this year, so I feel good about that. What we saw was this, not al
componenttext: Yes. Andy, as you noticed, I didn't really talk about the industry and the market because it's hard to make that call right now. While I did talk about weather, I didn't find about weather this year, so I feel good about that. What we saw was this, not alluded to in my comments. Last year, if you remember the weather, it was pretty harsh in December, January and first 3 weeks in February. And it was harsh in areas where typically you don't see it, Charlotte, Dallas, Atlanta and other places. And so we had some favorable comparisons in late December, January and February. Unfortunately, January and February are not exactly big months for us. Then if you recall last year, there's a little bit of a accounting favor impact up North and people got out in March because they needed to get out. And then March was reasonably mild and so is April, and so the Kansan started earlier. So we had good volume in March and April relative to the rest of the year last year, and I think we're seeing softer volume this year. What I'm trying to say here is I think weather is impacting that, I just don't know to what degree. And I think I can make a better call on that after we see May and June year because we'll be back apples-to-apples. In terms of what I read and what I hear, it's probably not a whole lot different than you. The good news here is that the consumer sentiment is positive. It's up and down a little bit, but it's still positive. The sentiment of our restaurant operators is positive. It's remained positive. So I think people are generally seeing at least maintaining -- they're seeing good things, and they're hopeful that it'll translate into better things. Probably the biggest positive out there right now, I would say, would be the lower fuel prices. They come back a little bit, but all in all, the consumer is getting a raise, if you will, the pump. What's not clear there at all is to what degree. It appears the consumer is paying down debt with some of that, saving some of that and spending some of that. It's not clear how much of that we're getting, perhaps some, but I don't think a lot at this point. With that said, I think to the extent that the fuel prices stayed down for up an extended period of time, that will be good for our customers and I would expect that, that will help us over time. So it's a long way of saying it's hard for me to really explain what's going on in the market right now because of kind of the unusual weather comparisons as well as the impact of fuel. But I think we'll have a better read on this as we get into the summer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I was looking for more color, but I just wanted to clarify following up just on what you're saying. So you're not -- I mean, your preamble you said you're expect things to get better. Sounds like it's more of a macro view of the business and rather
componenttext: Okay. I was looking for more color, but I just wanted to clarify following up just on what you're saying. So you're not -- I mean, your preamble you said you're expect things to get better. Sounds like it's more of a macro view of the business and rather than something you've seen in the last week or 2 as the trend turned up?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I expect the macro to clear up is what I try to say. I wish I could give you more. In terms of our performance, what I alluded to in my comments, was march was softer and April softer. But again, I do think some of that is the comparisons, we'll see
componenttext: Well, I expect the macro to clear up is what I try to say. I wish I could give you more. In terms of our performance, what I alluded to in my comments, was march was softer and April softer. But again, I do think some of that is the comparisons, we'll see. But so let's summarize here. You got moderate inflation. You've got some FX. Let's put that aside. And then you've got some softer volumes in March and April. I would expect it to pick up. I'm still very pleased with what we're doing. We're growing our volume both on the local side and the corporate side. So relative to the market, I'm pleased with where we're at there.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask Chris a question on the incentive compensation accrual account you called. It's kind of a housekeeping, but seem like quite a big number compared to trend and well-above what the stock option would be. Did that I do that Math right? A
componenttext: I just wanted to ask Chris a question on the incentive compensation accrual account you called. It's kind of a housekeeping, but seem like quite a big number compared to trend and well-above what the stock option would be. Did that I do that Math right? And can you give some explanation why the accrual was so big?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not so sure. I can't respond to the last part of compared to what you're seeking, but the accrual itself is just what we anticipate paying out on the incentive accruals versus where we are on our objectives. And on a year-over-year basis, we're j
componenttext: Yes, I'm not so sure. I can't respond to the last part of compared to what you're seeking, but the accrual itself is just what we anticipate paying out on the incentive accruals versus where we are on our objectives. And on a year-over-year basis, we're just in a much better place. So last year at this time, we were not hitting our bonus-able objectives, and so we had very little accrued. This year, we are accruing still at target because we are on pace to hit those objectives. So on a year-over-year basis, that's where you get the increase.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you're saying on trend with the prior quarters. There's no catch up to Q3, just you're on trend with a bonus accrual?
componenttext: Okay. So you're saying on trend with the prior quarters. There's no catch up to Q3, just you're on trend with a bonus accrual?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not this year. Yes, this year there's been no catch up from quarter-to-quarter. No, last year, it bounced around because every quarter you got to look very our versus those objectives, and so we went to the first quarter fine but the end we had to start r
componenttext: Not this year. Yes, this year there's been no catch up from quarter-to-quarter. No, last year, it bounced around because every quarter you got to look very our versus those objectives, and so we went to the first quarter fine but the end we had to start reducing the accrual and 3 [ph] because we're no longer on track to hit that target.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fine. So you were just calling a tough comparison, and we can do the adjustment if we like. Is that what it is?
componenttext: Fine. So you were just calling a tough comparison, and we can do the adjustment if we like. Is that what it is?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's really all it is. Like I say, normally, I'd try to put things on an apples-to-apples basis as much as possible. And when I look at our performance this year, especially on operating expenses, I don't like to say well, we have to compare those incen
componenttext: That's really all it is. Like I say, normally, I'd try to put things on an apples-to-apples basis as much as possible. And when I look at our performance this year, especially on operating expenses, I don't like to say well, we have to compare those incentives versus a year whether there were no incentives whatsoever. Now we still have to pay for those incentives, and so those are real dollars, and they're really going to out the door, so we don't try to again excuse it much of it as you're looking in the percentage increase so I can try to do apples-to-apples. That's why we gave the number.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Kelly Bonior with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Kelly Bonior with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just curious in the quarter how you think about market share, what your market share may have been? And I ask because it looks like some of the broader industry sales trends at least for the restaurant seems did a very, very strong this quarter, so
componenttext: I was just curious in the quarter how you think about market share, what your market share may have been? And I ask because it looks like some of the broader industry sales trends at least for the restaurant seems did a very, very strong this quarter, so I was just curious what you would think how you performed relative to the industry during the quarter?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take that one, Kelly. First one, we don't track market share quarterly. We look at annually through different industries, so first, primarily economics. And we look at the overall market U.S. and Canada and obviously, we look at our numbers. And gene
componenttext: I'll take that one, Kelly. First one, we don't track market share quarterly. We look at annually through different industries, so first, primarily economics. And we look at the overall market U.S. and Canada and obviously, we look at our numbers. And generally, if you go back and look at longer term, Sysco has been able to grow share about 0.5 point a year. I think we're continuing to do that. I can't really speak to this quarter on a market share because I don't have the market data. Certainly, there were some strength in our customer base but not throughout the quarter and certainly not with our customers. So again, I was pleased with our through the business, but we don't see track that quarterly.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I could just follow-up with one more. Just in light of McDonald's announcement to shift towards using antibiotic-free chicken on their menu, so I was just curious how Sysco is may be positioned in terms of supply of antibiotic-free chicken?
componenttext: Got it. And if I could just follow-up with one more. Just in light of McDonald's announcement to shift towards using antibiotic-free chicken on their menu, so I was just curious how Sysco is may be positioned in terms of supply of antibiotic-free chicken? Do see that as an opportunity? What kind of conversations are you having with suppliers and your customers around these products? And what could any sales and margin implications for Sysco be if there's a broader shift from your customers to products like this?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If I could broaden the question a little bit, not just chicken but in general. That's one of the key things that we think category management will help us focus on with a broader like, which is to working with our suppliers and our customers is to be
componenttext: Yes. If I could broaden the question a little bit, not just chicken but in general. That's one of the key things that we think category management will help us focus on with a broader like, which is to working with our suppliers and our customers is to better understand what the customers' needs are and how we can as we optimize our SKUs and strategize together, do a better job of positioning product and where the customer wants to see it, whether it's organic or local or whatever, what's important to them. So with us, it always looks the way you posed the question, which is what's important to customer, what does the customer need and we're doing a lot of work on the customer side through the marketing department, customer loyalty initiatives to understand customer needs and then connecting that to work that we're doing with our suppliers and category management and the day-to-day provide us to better optimize our SKUs. Now it's early days and plenty of work there to do, but there are some big opportunity for us going forward. And I would also say to you, we have over the years made some good progress on the sustainability front, and I think you'll see us continue to raise the profile of that work within the company. And that group will work very closely with our customers but also with our merchandising and our marketing team. So bottom line is we do everything we can to understand what the needs of our customers are. I think we're better positioned to do that going forward, and I think we can speak more specifically about that as time goes on.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Mark both, from Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Mark both, from Jefferies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you just give a little more detail on what we could expect from the core action this week? How long will it take before we hear a decision? And if the court rules for you, is it a foregone conclusion that if things would just approve the approved as
componenttext: Could you just give a little more detail on what we could expect from the core action this week? How long will it take before we hear a decision? And if the court rules for you, is it a foregone conclusion that if things would just approve the approved as stated or do you still need to negotiate with the FTC? And if there's a ruling against you, how long does it take to get through the administrative hearing with the FTC?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great questions, Mark. This is new ground for all of us. I would say, as far as the timing, obviously, that's in the hands of the judge in terms of how long the process take. The hearing starts tomorrow and the judges gives was up to 7 days we'll go throu
componenttext: Great questions, Mark. This is new ground for all of us. I would say, as far as the timing, obviously, that's in the hands of the judge in terms of how long the process take. The hearing starts tomorrow and the judges gives was up to 7 days we'll go through the end of next week and then they'll be some as I understand some brief serve papers followed by each side with the judge to review, and then he'll take the time he needs to come back with a ruling. So we don't know exactly how long that is, but I would think it's closer 2 weeks than months. And again, that's his call. As far as what happens, as I said in my comments, if we were to prevail, then I think there's a short period of time we're the FTC has an opportunity to decide whether they want appealed or not that we would wait on that and then go from there. If they were to prevail, we'll sit down internally and then sit down with the sponsors and the owners of US Foods and charter quarters from there as well. And to be determined, but that's still different ways it could play out.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe you could talk about the state of US Foods while we're waiting because we have seen margin declines in their business through the year we've been waiting for this deal to close?
componenttext: Maybe you could talk about the state of US Foods while we're waiting because we have seen margin declines in their business through the year we've been waiting for this deal to close?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I really can't comment much on US Foods. I think it goes without saying that this process has taken longer than we would have liked, and it's probably been harder on them than it has been on us. So early days, they lost some sales people I think you're sa
componenttext: I really can't comment much on US Foods. I think it goes without saying that this process has taken longer than we would have liked, and it's probably been harder on them than it has been on us. So early days, they lost some sales people I think you're sales were hurt. I'm not so soon after it nor should I'd be in terms of its full year margins at right now and obviously, they've pulled back here some and integration planning over the last months. I should probably leave it at that. I probably shouldn't be commenting on US Foods.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: SYGMA, in general, had a very strong year in fiscal '14 and has been pretty slow year-over-year to this point fiscal '15. Can you shed some light in terms of what's happened there, whether some by choice, maybe some wasn't by choice and what -- how you fe
componenttext: SYGMA, in general, had a very strong year in fiscal '14 and has been pretty slow year-over-year to this point fiscal '15. Can you shed some light in terms of what's happened there, whether some by choice, maybe some wasn't by choice and what -- how you feel about the overall growth of that segment over time?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I'll start and Chris could jump too. I would say it's been a couple of years since SYGMA had a strong year, and it's got a lot of attention. We have restructured there somewhat and Greg Keller over SYGMA full time, and Greg grew up in SYGMA
componenttext: Thanks, John. I'll start and Chris could jump too. I would say it's been a couple of years since SYGMA had a strong year, and it's got a lot of attention. We have restructured there somewhat and Greg Keller over SYGMA full time, and Greg grew up in SYGMA business. He's been raining our national sales area up until the last several months, so he is very well-versed in the SYGMA of the business. He's very well connected with our customer base. He's got a lot of passion for that business. So I believe we're in good hands there from leadership. There are some things that we're working on their both in terms of how do we better position ourselves in terms of the needs of those customers and still run expenses very tight, so it's a very transaction, service-oriented business, not with a lot of touches like the Broadline, but there's no very little margin for here in SYGMA. So we had to invest in money over the last year or so in terms of facilities and drivers and people like that, things like that to strengthen the business, and that's hurt us on the bottom line. We've also had to just take a look at how well we run the business overall. So I'd say we're in transition with SYGMA. We like the business strategically. It's a very -- that customer base or potential customer base is a big part of the overall opportunity, and it's always nice when you're seeing how customers or perspective customers to give them a choice in terms of which model they would prefer to model or the Broadline model. And the reality is sometimes they prefer both depending on their locations and our position. So somewhat in transition there, work to do strategically, still very important to the company.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Has there been, yes, hi.
componenttext: Has there been, yes, hi.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just add a couple of points. As Bill said, it's a business where expense control is incredibly important. It's a low-margin business. There have been some regulatory changes on the transportation side drivers and things like that. That while we can h
