componenttext: Yes. Just add a couple of points. As Bill said, it's a business where expense control is incredibly important. It's a low-margin business. There have been some regulatory changes on the transportation side drivers and things like that. That while we can handle those fairly well in the Broadline, they affect SYGMA disproportionately and we're having to overcome some of those things. And as Bill said, we've got to look at the model and continue to find ways to offset increases like that. So I would echo the statement that it's in transition. We've got some work to do.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Has there been any significant account loss that maybe been covered up by some accounts gains? And as you kind of look forward over the next couple of years, do you have any big chain opportunities to add that could be coming up for bid?
componenttext: Has there been any significant account loss that maybe been covered up by some accounts gains? And as you kind of look forward over the next couple of years, do you have any big chain opportunities to add that could be coming up for bid?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's been overly significant account less. SYGMA is no different than the rest of the business. There's a lot of pricing pressure in that business, and so we've had to deal with that as well along the way as we've looked at expenses. But
componenttext: I don't think there's been overly significant account less. SYGMA is no different than the rest of the business. There's a lot of pricing pressure in that business, and so we've had to deal with that as well along the way as we've looked at expenses. But again, Greg is a very strong leader, very strong sales guy. So I'm quite optimistic that we'll continue to find the right mix of customers and do a good job for them. But again, the way we look at SYGMA today is we want to understand what the customers are looking for, with kind of model, what level of support, what economics are they willing to incur. And if that's the SYGMA model, then fine. If it's not, then we'll put them into Broadline. They go back and forth. And as I said, some customers utilize both models. So I think we're in good place there in terms of the direction. But from a customer standpoint, we look at it across the entire spectrum, which is what does the customer want in terms of the trade-off of service and pricing.

componenttext: I wanted to just go back about the products for a second. When -- and it sounds like early stages, but so far, if you been seeing any incremental demand increases from more of your customers wanting natural organic types of products, would you say that so far you been able to have access to the supplies, you been able to meet demands and that now is continuing through category management and that's something that will continue to evolve. Is that fair to say at this point?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Vinny, that's what I'm trying to say. So, yes, we definitely see that trend over the last few years. That's a trend and I have to tell you the scheme of what we do. It's not -- yes, it's not a huge amount of the business which creates part of the cha
componenttext: Hey, Vinny, that's what I'm trying to say. So, yes, we definitely see that trend over the last few years. That's a trend and I have to tell you the scheme of what we do. It's not -- yes, it's not a huge amount of the business which creates part of the challenge where you need enough volume and enough velocity to make it work or the supplier and on the cost side and for the customer. So I would say it's like a lot of things in Sysco today. There certainly parts of the country in certain outpost where we do a very good job on the local side and fresh side, and then there's other not so good and that's where I see the work in merchandise and the category management, in particular, with innovation giving us a position to be more consistent. And by doing that, crate more volume, which will make the more economical. So the trends have definitely been there. We're responding to them. We just -- we need to continue to get better at it, and we need to continue to grow the volumes to make it work for everybody.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

componenttext: All right, that makes sense. And then just a quick follow-up. Inflation that you didn't see moderate over the quarter. Was anything kind of internally surprising to you versus your forecast from a particular category-specific standpoint? And then maybe just additional color with your thoughts on inflation overall as we get through the rest of this year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, you surprised me. I guess probably fell off faster than I thought it would be from that standpoint. It doesn't surprise me that dairy is down, for example, and dairy is a volatile category. But the fact that several categories are essentially flat, t
componenttext: Yes, you surprised me. I guess probably fell off faster than I thought it would be from that standpoint. It doesn't surprise me that dairy is down, for example, and dairy is a volatile category. But the fact that several categories are essentially flat, that's probably a little surprising. And I think as far as the rest of the year, I can't -- if you're going to give me a fiscal year, I can't probably look that far ahead. And I think we talked about this with John earlier. I would expect inflation to moderate somewhat more, but still expect to see some low level of inflation here this quarter.

componenttext: I apologize if this was -- if I missed this earlier. But one of the things that stood out to me in the operating business line was that your liberty costs were lower, and I wondered if you could speak to that if there was an anomaly this quarter or whether that's a trend that you expect to continue in light of the fact that we've been hearing that truck driver shortages continue to plague firms across a number of industries?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was mainly driven, at least in our case, it was mainly driven by lower fuel costs, which we called out. So if the truck driver shortage abating, I would say that it's not getting any worse. We've kind of learned how to handle it although it's not
componenttext: Yes, it was mainly driven, at least in our case, it was mainly driven by lower fuel costs, which we called out. So if the truck driver shortage abating, I would say that it's not getting any worse. We've kind of learned how to handle it although it's not exactly easy. But this particular quarter, we just started to see some benefit from fuel. And as you recall quarter or so ago, we talked about we start seeing some benefit at the back half of the year and this is it.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: To add, I think where we have driver shortages and it weren't self-inflicted, it's generally in these areas where there's been a lot of drilling, a lot of energy. And so as that subsided somewhat, I think that's actually created a little more capacity. So
componenttext: To add, I think where we have driver shortages and it weren't self-inflicted, it's generally in these areas where there's been a lot of drilling, a lot of energy. And so as that subsided somewhat, I think that's actually created a little more capacity. Sooner all the way back there, but I think that pressure is a little bit less than what it was 6 or 9 months ago.

componenttext: Yes, it's affecting some of the supply you're reading and that obviously has some impact out there. It's only if it starts affecting a very large part of the supply, not just here in the U.S. but offshore as well that it begins to impact our ability to find product and strategy our customers. Thus far, that's not the case, but it still -- we watch this stuff. We set up crisis teams when it's important and when it becomes relevant.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
