This include, but is not limited to, risk factors contained in our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended June 28, 2014, subsequent SEC filings and in the news release issued earlier this morning. A copy of these materials can be found in the Investors section at sysco.com or via Sysco's IR app.
Non-GAAP financial measures are included in our comments today and in our presentation slides. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the applicable GAAP measures are included at the end of the presentation, and can also be found in the Investors section of our website.
All comments about earnings per share refer to diluted earnings per share unless otherwise noted. In addition, all references to case volume include total Broadline and SYGMA combined. [Operator Instructions]
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to our President and CEO, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shannon. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, Sysco reported third quarter fiscal 2015 financial results. Sales increased 4% to $11.7 billion, adjusted operating income decreased 3% to $377 million. Adjusted ne
componenttext:
Thanks, Shannon. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, Sysco reported third quarter fiscal 2015 financial results. Sales increased 4% to $11.7 billion, adjusted operating income decreased 3% to $377 million. Adjusted net earnings increased 7% to $238 million, and EPS increased 5% to $0.40 for the quarter. Net earnings and EPS for the quarter were in line with our expectations, as solid volume and gross profit dollar growth along with a favorable tax rate, offset the impact of moderating inflation trends and favorable foreign exchange translation and higher-than-planned operating expenses.
Case volume grew 2.5% for the quarter, and we were pleased with our growth both with locally managed and corporate managed customers. Overall, weather was not a major factor in our year-over-year comparisons for the quarter, as we benefited from favorable comparisons in January and February, but were hampered by severe weather in the Northeast and Mideast in late February and most of March.
This last point is important to note because March provides a disproportionally large portion of our third quarter volume, and was a relatively mild weather month last year. We experienced similar trends in April, but expect the year-over-year monthly impact of weather will dissipate as we move into May and June.
We continue to roll out and successfully execute our category management initiative, and the benefits from this process contributed to our gross profit dollar growth during the quarter. Through category management, we were able to support our customer's growth by lowering our product cost and developing innovative product development ideas. This is vital to mitigating gross margin pressure as we move forward in what remains a fiercely competitive market environment.
Regarding expense management, we established appropriately aggressive goals for cost per case management for fiscal 2015. After a very strong expense management performance in the prior year. We experienced modest improvement in sequential trends in the third quarter, but will fall short of our original goals in this area for the year.
With that said, our entire leadership team is intently focused on enhancing productivity in a sustainable manner, while delivering exceptional service to our customers. I expect our performance trends in this area to improve modestly in the fourth quarter and more so in fiscal 2016.
Moving to our multiyear business transformation initiatives, we are pleased with the progress we've made on achieving the steady-state cost-savings goals we set as we began fiscal 2013. Fiscal 2015 is the third year of that financial road map and we've already exceeded our original target of $600 million, which was comprised of approximately $300 million in annual savings in both operating and product costs.
While pleased with this progress we've made over the past 3 years on these initiatives, it's more clear than ever that transforming Sysco's business will be a perpetual process as we strive to fully realize our vision of being our customer's most valued and trusted business partner.
Foundational to our ultimate success is further developing and continually enhancing our technology platform. We have now embedded this work in the overall scope of our business technology group under the leadership of Wayne Shurts. We have learned a great deal from the challenges we encountered in deploying SAP and all of the standardized processes it requires. 
Over the past 2 years under Wayne's leadership, we have refined our business processes, strengthened our technology support capabilities, stabilized the SAP system and enhanced its efficiency. While there's more work to be done, we are well positioned to move forward with a cohesive, enterprise-wide, modular-centric approach rather than our previous OpCo-by-OpCo multimodule approach. As our deployment process matures and evolves in the future, we expect this change to result in smoother conversions, better execution and an improved experience for our customers. 
On the acquisition front, we recently completed the previously announced agreement to acquire 50% of Pacific Star Foodservice, a leading foodservice distributor in Mexico. We have developed a strong relationship over the past several years with the ownership and management team at Pacific Star, and we are very excited about the potential opportunities that this partnership will provide to profitably grow our business in Mexico. 
Regarding our pending merger with US Foods, the hearing related to the FTC's motion for preliminary injunction begins tomorrow, May 5, and will last up to 7 business days. If we receive a ruling on our favor, we will proceed to closing unless the decision is appealed. In the event of an unfavorable ruling, we would assess together with US Foods' ownership whether to pursue the case further. We remain resolute in our belief that this transaction is procompetitive, good for our customers and will accelerate Sysco's business transformation. 
We announced in April that Joel Grade has been named Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer effective September 1, 2015, following Chris Kreidler's decision to leave the company. Joel is a veteran Sysco leader with nearly 20 years of experience in key finance and commercial roles. He is uniquely suited to step into the CFO position because of his deep knowledge of our local operations and people. We are fortunate to have a leader like Joel ready to take on this key position, and I look forward to working closely with him in his new role as we move forward. 
We appreciate the numerous important contributions Chris has made on Sysco's behalf since joining us 5 years ago. He has agreed to remain as CFO through August, and he will work closely with Joel and Sysco's senior executive team to ensure an orderly transition of his responsibilities, including staying on through the end of December as an adviser. 
In closing, I am pleased with the consistent case growth we've seen in our locally managed and corporate managed business, which demonstrates our associates' unwavering focus on providing consistent and excellent service to our customers. In addition, our leadership team is making good progress in driving out initiatives to enhance both gross profit dollar growth and expense management. Our ongoing work to fundamentally reshape our company is challenging but gratifying, and we strongly believe that the steps we are taking will reinforce our leadership position in the ever-evolving foodservice industry. 
Now I'll turn things over to Chris so he can provide additional details on our financial results for the third quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, sales were $11.7 billion, an increase of 4.2% compared to the prior year. Our sales growth rate was substantially lower than the 7% rate we saw during the first half of the fiscal year becau
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, sales were $11.7 billion, an increase of 4.2% compared to the prior year. Our sales growth rate was substantially lower than the 7% rate we saw during the first half of the fiscal year because of the rapid decline in food cost inflation and the impact of foreign exchange translation.
Food cost inflation declined significantly from 6% in the second quarter to 3.7% in the third quarter. Our estimates for food cost inflation represents the weighted average change in Sysco's cost for the same products year-over-year. At 3.7%, it would appear we are getting close to what we normally describe as the sweet spot for inflation of 2% to 3%, but the 3.7% is an average across all of our product lines and sometimes averages don't tell the whole story as is the case here.
Specifically, the meat category experienced low double-digit inflation in the quarter, and poultry inflation was in the high single digits. On a weighted-average basis, these 2 categories accounted for 3.2% of the 3.7% inflation we experienced across all of our categories. At these levels, passing along all of the inflation can be painful to our customers putting gross margin under pressure. In addition, rapid declines in food cost also make it challenging to leverage our fixed costs. 
The impact of changes in foreign exchange rates had a much larger impact than usual this quarter. Similar to many companies with significant operations outside of the U.S., the strengthening dollar depressed our foreign sales as we converted them to U.S. dollars. This quarter's decrease of 1.3% was the highest in the past 3 years. The impact has typically been in the range of 0 to 0.5%. Sales from acquisitions increased sales by 0.6%. Case volume grew 2.5% during the quarter, including acquisitions and approximately 2.2% excluding acquisitions. Gross profit in the third quarter was $2.1 billion, a 3.1% increase, while gross margin declined 17 basis points to 17.52%. Benefits from category management contributed significantly to our gross profit during the quarter. 
In addition, case volume growth for our locally managed Broadline business continued to increase slightly on a sequential basis as it has done the last 2 quarters. Solid local case growth is important to drive gross profit dollar growth. Case growth for our corporate managed customers remained strong, but competitive pricing pressure in this segment contributed to gross margin pressure. Certain items for the third quarter totaled $91 million and related to merger and integration planning expenses and interest on the merger debt. Of this amount, $50 million was recorded in operating expense and $41 million was recorded in interest expense. 
Merger and integration planning costs that impacted operating expenses were mainly related to work to prepare for the integration of the 2 companies' technology platforms. These expenses in total were lower in the third quarter compared to levels in the first half of the year, as we scaled back our integration planning work in certain areas where a significant amount of work has already been completed. Merger cost that impacted interest expense relates to the debt that we issued last October that is intended to refinance US Foods' debt upon closing of the transaction. We are treating this interest expense as a certain item until the merger closes. 
Adjusted operating expenses for the third quarter increased $73 million or 4.5% due to a $61 million increase in payroll expense. Payroll expense increased mainly due to higher pay for our sales organization as a result of higher gross profit, investments in new administrative support capabilities, higher incentive accruals and newly-acquired operations. These increases were partially offset by lower delivery costs, mainly driven by savings and fuel expense. After excluding incentives, adjusted operating expenses would have increased 3.9%. 
Our cost per case performance improved modestly from earlier in the year, but as Bill mentioned, expense management remains a challenge for us. Adjusted cost per case performance for the third quarter in the North American Broadline business, which is the portion of the business we've given guidance on previously, increased only $0.03 in the third quarter. However, excluding the benefit from currency translation, cost per case would have increased by $0.09. We have previously said we expect cost per case to increase between $0.05 and $0.10 this year. We would expect to be on the low end of this range, including the impact of foreign exchange, and on the high end of this range, excluding foreign exchange. We are focused on driving improvement across our operations with multiple initiatives that implement best practices, enhance our operating training programs and improve our ability to measure and analyze our performance. 
Adjusted operating income from the quarter was $377 million, down 2.7% from the prior year, and adjusted operating margin was 3.2%, down 23 basis points from last year. Our effective tax rate in the third quarter was 34% compared to 39% in the prior year period. This quarter's rate was positively impacted by the favorable resolution of state tax matter. In the prior year, the rate was elevated due to the nondeductible portion of a $20 million legal settlement that we disclosed at the time. Normalizing for these types of discrete events, our tax rate would be roughly 37%. This is lower than our historical rates due to the increasing amount of business earnings and international jurisdictions that have lower tax rates, as well as reduced state taxes from legal restructurings. 
Adjusted net earnings increased 7% to $238 million, and adjusted EPS increased 5.3% to $0.40. Cash flow performance in the first 39 weeks of the year was relatively strong after taking into account the cash impact of certain items. Cash flow from operations increased $12 million to $860 million versus last year. This increase reflects the negative impact of 2 items. First, the cash impact of certain items increased $82 million year-over-year, mainly due to merger and integration planning expenses. Second, as we disclosed earlier this year, we made a $50 million pension contribution this year compared to none in the prior year period. This difference is simply driven by a different timing regarding when we make cash contributions each year.
Cash tax payments were $135 million lower than last year due to a lower effective tax rate, which I discussed a moment ago, and merger and integration planning expenses that reduced taxable earnings. Free cash flow was $439 million in the first 39 weeks of fiscal 2015 compared to $484 million in the prior year period, or a reduction of $46 million. However, after adjusting for the cash impact of certain items and the increase in pension contribution I mentioned a moment ago, free cash flow was $617 million, an increase of $86 million or 16% from the prior year period.
Capital expenditures for the first 39 weeks of the year, net of proceeds from sale of assets, increased $58 million to $422 million. About $53 million of this increase is due to IT-related merger integration planning and the rest was due to timing of investments in our fleet. 
Our cash flow from operations and free cash flow are always impacted by foreign currency translation, but the impact of the first of 39 weeks of fiscal 2015 is much greater than the last few years. You will see in the cash flow statement a $77 million impact this year compared to less than $0.5 million last year. This means our cash flows would have been $77 million higher on a constant dollar basis. 
Turning to an update on recent acquisitions. Last month, we completed the previously announced transaction to buy 50% of Pacific Star Foodservice, a leading foodservice distributor in Mexico. Pacific Star has operated since 1989 with distribution centers servicing customers in the major metropolitan areas of Mexico City, Guadalajara, Monterrey and Tijuana. It primarily services chain accounts, including fast food and casual dining restaurants, casinos, theme parks, movie theaters and hotels throughout Mexico.
This partnership fits our international expansion strategy, allows us to enhance service to our U.S. customers who operate in the region and provides growth opportunities in an important region of the Americas. In addition, subsequent to the end of the quarter, we announced our agreement to acquire Tannis Trading in Canada. Tannis operates in the Ottawa market, the fourth largest in Canada. This acquisition, which remains subject to regulatory approval, would allow us to better serve our customers and achieve our goal of increasing sales in Canada. 
Regarding our outlook for the remainder of the year, there are a few additional items I'd like to point out. First, as we discussed last quarter, because of the pending merger during this fiscal year, we have not been in the market buying back shares to offset dilution from incentive-based compensation as we would normally be doing. This has had the effect of increasing our shares outstanding in the first 39 weeks of the fiscal year due to the exercise of employee stock options and divesting of restricted stock units. As a result, both adjusted and reported diluted EPS were lower by $0.005 in the third quarter and $0.015 over the first 39 weeks.
Unless we repurchased shares during the fourth quarter, we estimate that our diluted shares outstanding may be greater than 597 million shares in the fiscal year. This estimate is dependent on the level of stock option exercises and RSU vesting that occurs and does not include the impact of the shares to be issued in conjunction with the pending US Foods merger. Second, please note that we plan to pay off $300 million in bonds that come due in mid-June. We currently anticipate using cash on hand to fund this payment. Lastly, our forecast for capital expenditures, net of proceeds from asset sales, remains at $500 million to $500 million -- sorry, $500 million to $550 million for fiscal year 2015, but we now expect to be at the high end of this range for the year.
In closing, while our top line has been negatively impacted by lower levels of inflation and the larger impact from foreign currency translation, we are pleased that the business continues to generate solid case volume growth, in particular, in the locally managed portion of our business. We have opportunities to improve our operating expense management and have begun to make some progress in this area. But importantly, the business continues to generate strong free cash flow. While we have work ahead of us to transform the business, there are many exciting initiatives underway that will enhance our customers' experience, strengthen our operating performance and increase profitability. 
With that, operator, we'll now take some questions.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from John Heinbockel with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from John Heinbockel with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I actually have a tactical question and a strategic one. So Bill, on the tactical side, it would seem that inflation probably moderates a bit further than here. Can you offset that with cost reduction? Or is the uncertainty around US Foods and kind of
componenttext: So I actually have a tactical question and a strategic one. So Bill, on the tactical side, it would seem that inflation probably moderates a bit further than here. Can you offset that with cost reduction? Or is the uncertainty around US Foods and kind of where the business sits today hamstringing you from doing that? And then I have a strategic one.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, we have to. I mean so, yes, do I think we can? We've -- in the past we've been able to adjust our expenses accordingly, and I agree with your premise. I think you could see the inflation come down a little bit more just for the reasons Chris said, w
componenttext: John, we have to. I mean so, yes, do I think we can? We've -- in the past we've been able to adjust our expenses accordingly, and I agree with your premise. I think you could see the inflation come down a little bit more just for the reasons Chris said, we've got a couple of categories that are pretty high. And the others -- you got dairy is very volatile, as you know, so dairy is down a little bit. Seafood is down a little bit, but seafood is not a big part of the overall mix. So I think essentially, you're looking at an environment today where you've got 2 categories, meat and poultry that are high, which is difficult to pass along in a fast way and the right way. And the others are pretty much neutral if you put them all together. And yes, I expect that to continue here at least for the, whatever, a few, couple, 3 months as far as we can see out. As I said in my comments, we're seeing improvement on the expenses sequentially, we're not just seeing as fast as we have planned. And I think you will see more expense improvement here in the fourth quarter relative to the first part of the year, and we're certainly planning to do even more for next year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then strategically -- and I think you haven't -- don't want to talk about this, but have you done much planning if US Foods doesn't happen? And what would you do differently than you're doing today if that doesn't come to fruition?
componenttext: And then strategically -- and I think you haven't -- don't want to talk about this, but have you done much planning if US Foods doesn't happen? And what would you do differently than you're doing today if that doesn't come to fruition?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, one of the things I feel pretty good about is we've done a nice job here. We've spent some money doing it, separating running the business day to day and keeping our people, the vast majority of our people focused on taking care of the
componenttext: Well, first of all, one of the things I feel pretty good about is we've done a nice job here. We've spent some money doing it, separating running the business day to day and keeping our people, the vast majority of our people focused on taking care of their customers and running their business and not having them be distracted by the merger. And then we have another group of people and outside support folks who've done a great job, under Chris' and Greg Bertrand's leadership, driving out a very sound integration plan. So I feel good about what we've done to date. Yes, we've done some contingent planning and it's not fully developed. We've had discussions as a management team and with our board, and we'll continue to have those discussions. And once we have a ruling, then we'll probably take some more time, but not a lot of time, and go forth from there with some other strategic directions. But -- so yes, we've done some planning, but not in a position today to really talk a whole lot about that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.And we'll move on to Edward Kelly with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext:
And we'll take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
And we'll move on to Edward Kelly with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just have a -- I actually have a follow-up to John's question here. Bill, in the past, you guys have mentioned international M&A as an area of interest. I mean, obviously, the U.S. market is top-of-mind right now. But if material consolidation is not po
componenttext: I just have a -- I actually have a follow-up to John's question here. Bill, in the past, you guys have mentioned international M&A as an area of interest. I mean, obviously, the U.S. market is top-of-mind right now. But if material consolidation is not possible here, like where are your heads today on international relative to where they were in the past? Is it still something that you'd be interested in?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly. As you heard, we're pleased with the joint venture that we have just finalized with our partners down in Mexico. And we've gradually built out some small footprint in Costa Rica and now Mexico, Bahamas, Ireland. Canada was the first one obvious
componenttext: Certainly. As you heard, we're pleased with the joint venture that we have just finalized with our partners down in Mexico. And we've gradually built out some small footprint in Costa Rica and now Mexico, Bahamas, Ireland. Canada was the first one obviously. So I think where we are thereat is, I think, just a matter of place to place. And we definitely -- and we talked about the strategy of the company. The fifth point we talk about is always looking for other areas to expand whether it be through adjacencies or geographics. And I just see it more as a -- something we need to do continually. And over the next 3 to 5 years, I would like to think that we'll continue to find good partners in different parts of the world where our customers value our capabilities and find ways to grow there, primarily to lay a foundation for the future beyond that. So I see international more as something we need to do. We need to continually build it for the medium- to long-term. Short- to medium-term, obviously, US Foods is a big, big part of our strategy. It's not our strategy, it's a big part of the strategy. If that were not to work out, we would revisit other strategic opportunities that we looked at in the past and look our capital structure, all those types of things. We're just not in a position today to talk a whole a lot about it.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Bill, when you think about the U.S. business now, there's obviously always puts and takes and what impacts the earnings. I mean, the backdrop doesn't really seem to be too bad right now with what's going on with restaurant sales and lower fuel. But th
componenttext: And Bill, when you think about the U.S. business now, there's obviously always puts and takes and what impacts the earnings. I mean, the backdrop doesn't really seem to be too bad right now with what's going on with restaurant sales and lower fuel. But this quarter, you're back to EBITDA actually being down a little bit year-over-year after a couple of quarters of good growth. And I guess, the question is, what's it's really saying about the outlook for the business, I guess, absent the deal? And you touched on it a little bit, but is there a need for some larger strategic refresh or restructuring if the transaction were not to happen? Or are you really just -- is it really more about fine-tuning?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think both, all right? So we need to manage what we have the ability to control the most, which is our business, and we're pretty good at running our business. Obviously, as we've said for a while now, the market environment we're in is difficult. It's
componenttext: I think both, all right? So we need to manage what we have the ability to control the most, which is our business, and we're pretty good at running our business. Obviously, as we've said for a while now, the market environment we're in is difficult. It's very competitive, and it's not like many other industries and we don't expect that to change. So again, to kind of recap how we look at the world, we see modest medium- to long-term growth in the industry. We expect to grow faster than that. To do that, we need to differentiate ourselves ongoing-ly with our customers and we need to take cost out of the system. It's one of the reasons why this merger is so important to us. If the merger doesn't happen, we'll need to find other ways to continue to do that. We may not get there quite as fast, but I'm confident we'll continue to go in the right direction. Specifically, to this quarter, you can look at it a lot of different ways. The bottom line is we didn't manage our expenses as well as we would have liked. If we had managed our cost at least maybe just $0.05 better, I think you would have seen a different result here, and I would've been -- I wouldn't have talked as much about planned expenses. So we're going to have quarters where there's inflation and less inflation. And we had good volume growth, as I said. We managed gross profit reasonably well given the environment. We just didn't bring our expenses in line as fast as we planned. And I expect that we'll get better at that here over the next 2 or 3 quarters.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just curious, I mean, I know we've talked a lot about the expense issue, and I guess I'm still confused as to why it's such -- it's been a problem now for 2 quarters in a row. I mean, I know you pointed to some things in terms of comps that affected expen
componenttext: Just curious, I mean, I know we've talked a lot about the expense issue, and I guess I'm still confused as to why it's such -- it's been a problem now for 2 quarters in a row. I mean, I know you pointed to some things in terms of comps that affected expenses, but anything else you can kind of put some color on?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll do my best, Karen. I would say this quarter was a little different in that our selling expense was higher than what it was in the first half of the year. We were up a couple of pennies the first year in selling, and that's -- that was fine. We had a
componenttext: I'll do my best, Karen. I would say this quarter was a little different in that our selling expense was higher than what it was in the first half of the year. We were up a couple of pennies the first year in selling, and that's -- that was fine. We had a lot of gross profit dollar growth and that's going to drive selling expense. So this quarter was up more than that. It's still probably fine, but it just can't be sustained. I mean, it's just -- we just have a situation where seasonally, it's a low-volume quarter. It's also a time that we bring M.A.s on in terms of training. And we had some operating companies that were behind in our headcount, and I think that put some pressure on us here as well. So selling cost is a little higher than what we planned. On the operations side, we're making progress. We're driving out a lot of change here, Karen. And we've been driving out very aggressively over the last year, 2 years, and that puts a lot of stress on the operating companies at a time when they still need to provide really solid service to our customers. And so there's been some challenges in terms of how fast you can drive that change and how well it's received by our workforce and how well our leadership, including me, are able to drive that out. So what we're doing here is transforming the company and we're bringing more standardization to our best practices in the field. We're functionalizing that part of our business in terms of the OpCo and our end-to-end supply chain organization now, and it's just taking a little longer to get where we want to go. The good news is we are seeing sequential relative improvement, and that's what gives me some confidence here.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Karen, this is Chris. I'll jump in and just elaborate on one point Bill made. Remember, a couple of years ago, we talked quite a bit about some of the changes we made in our sales organization, and we saw that disruption. We saw that disruption and it slo
componenttext: Karen, this is Chris. I'll jump in and just elaborate on one point Bill made. Remember, a couple of years ago, we talked quite a bit about some of the changes we made in our sales organization, and we saw that disruption. We saw that disruption and it slowed growth in terms of case volume on the local side especially, and we talked quite a bit about it at the time. We pushed through a lot of change and it took a while for all that change to kind of be accepted and understood and appropriately reacted to in the field. I think what you're seeing now is somewhat similar going on the operating expense environment. We are, as Bill said, pushing out a lot of change. It's for the good. It's going to lead to better results in the future, but it's going to take a while for some of that change to actually drive all the way down to the operating company level. And I think that's part of what we're experiencing right now. Not an excuse. We need to manage it better, but I do think we're seeing some of that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, I mean, to your point on M.A.s and progress on the top line, I guess independent sales definitely seemed fairly strong, although SYGMA was weak. But anything to point to on what was driving the strength in independent?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, I mean, to your point on M.A.s and progress on the top line, I guess independent sales definitely seemed fairly strong, although SYGMA was weak. But anything to point to on what was driving the strength in independent?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's the good news. I mean, we -- when we talk about initiatives, they're not all about cost savings and I think what you're seeing there is some -- several things that we've done over the last 2 or 3 years starting with a CRM tool, catego
componenttext: Well, I think that's the good news. I mean, we -- when we talk about initiatives, they're not all about cost savings and I think what you're seeing there is some -- several things that we've done over the last 2 or 3 years starting with a CRM tool, category management, we're getting better executing that. Some basic things we're doing in terms of working with our M.A.s and training and how to segment more effectively our customers and product categories and just creating more continuity, if you will, between the corporate sales organization and the field sales organization, as well as the OpCos overall. So we're pleased both on the local side and on the corporate side. If you go back 4, 5 quarters, we had no growth on the local side. So I think that's a bright spot, and that's certainly is something we've emphasized and something we need to continue to emphasize.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Then -- and just last question on the expense side. What's driving the merger and integration increase? Because I guess I was under the impression that you had kind of completed all you could from a merger and integration expense perspective until you kno
componenttext: Then -- and just last question on the expense side. What's driving the merger and integration increase? Because I guess I was under the impression that you had kind of completed all you could from a merger and integration expense perspective until you know more or until hopefully you close the merger, and it still seemed to be -- I mean, it's still increasing.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's actually not increasing. On a sequential basis, it's starting to decline. We had our peak last quarter, Karen, it's coming down from there. But I'll take your question to where I think you want to go anyway, why is it not perhaps dropping faste
componenttext: Well, it's actually not increasing. On a sequential basis, it's starting to decline. We had our peak last quarter, Karen, it's coming down from there. But I'll take your question to where I think you want to go anyway, why is it not perhaps dropping faster? There are couple of reasons. I mean, the interest portion of that obviously is not going to go anywhere. But even on the operating expense portion, there is a lot of work that continues to be done to prepare the 2 IT systems to be able to merge. We're not touching the U.S. food system or vice versa, but we're creating the conduits that will be necessary to allow them to merge. Unfortunately, at this deal has drug out, we were able to stand down certain aspects of what we're doing from a planning perspective as we can stand them back up rather quickly. But a lot of other areas, we need all the time we could possibly get to be prepared for mergering and integrating, and we continued some of that work. So it's come down somewhat. I expect it to not increase again, of course, until we complete the transaction, and then of course we'll give you a new guidance.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Meredith Adler with Barclays.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Meredith Adler with Barclays.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk a little bit about cash. I've spent many years in fixed income land and cash is cash. You can't really define it, and it just looks to me like, in fact, you're not covering your dividend or didn't for the first time onto the year. And the
componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about cash. I've spent many years in fixed income land and cash is cash. You can't really define it, and it just looks to me like, in fact, you're not covering your dividend or didn't for the first time onto the year. And then, so I'm wondering, you have a $300 million payment you're going to make this year. Could you talk about -- are you going to borrow? Do have a revolving credit facility that you're going to borrow under? And if sort of the same thing holds true, if the deal does not go through, you probably will have -- your bonds will be put back to you, the $5 billion, but you're not sitting on that much cash. So what do you think happens? How do you fund that put if it happens?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take the 2 pieces of that, Meredith. First, the $300 million, as I mentioned, we will pay that out of the cash that we have sitting on the balance sheet, which is just shy of $5 billion. That's what we'll do initially. If we then repay the bon
componenttext: Yes, let me take the 2 pieces of that, Meredith. First, the $300 million, as I mentioned, we will pay that out of the cash that we have sitting on the balance sheet, which is just shy of $5 billion. That's what we'll do initially. If we then repay the bond because you correctly pointed out if the merger agreement terminates, there is a process for those to be redeemed, we would pay those back out. Whatever we can't pay out of cash, we would put into our credit facility. We do have a very large commercial paper line backstop by credit facility, about $1.5 billion, so we've got plenty of capacity put on the balance sheet. We would then look at whether we have enough capacity for just general working capital needs, and we'd looked at whether we need to term out some of the debt that we've taken on the balance sheet the last couple of years, the acquisitions we've done, et cetera. We would do that after that point in time when things settle out.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other question. You'd said that -- sorry?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other question. You'd said that -- sorry?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, do mind if I just jump in? Just on the cash point, I would just -- going back to the earlier questions we had, first of all, we're going to cover our dividend. If you adjust for the merger-related expenses and things like that, we're going to mo
componenttext: Meredith, do mind if I just jump in? Just on the cash point, I would just -- going back to the earlier questions we had, first of all, we're going to cover our dividend. If you adjust for the merger-related expenses and things like that, we're going to more than cover our dividend from free cash flow this year. And second of all, the way I look at cash is strategically, we included that capacity. So obviously, as you all know, we're very highly rated company from a debt perspective. We have plenty of debt capacity, and certainly, we want to utilize it prudently. But I'm very confident in our ability to fund whatever we need to fund.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not actually worried about liquidity. You're not going to run out of liquidity. My next question, just quickly, is about category management and cycling the improvements you've seen so far. I think the real cycle summoned this next quarter, but it sou
componenttext: I'm not actually worried about liquidity. You're not going to run out of liquidity. My next question, just quickly, is about category management and cycling the improvements you've seen so far. I think the real cycle summoned this next quarter, but it sounded like you had more coming. How do you think that balances out in terms of the benefit of the gross margin?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you're right. We'll finishing up the third year, and we said at the beginning capital management will be somewhat back-end loaded, and we've seen those benefits this year. I think the key -- the way I look at that, Meredith, it's just we're now matu
componenttext: Well, you're right. We'll finishing up the third year, and we said at the beginning capital management will be somewhat back-end loaded, and we've seen those benefits this year. I think the key -- the way I look at that, Meredith, it's just we're now maturing to a point where, while we speak about category management, it's truly is embedded in how we merchandise. And we have centralized merchandising here to a large extent, we certainly standardize all of it. We still do some locally in terms of working with suppliers. But for the most part, we're working with the suppliers here at corporate and then working closely with our operating companies. So from that standpoint, we've realized a lot of benefits, but we have some more launches here to do later this year into next year, and that's a significant part of the overall volume. And then I think what you'll see us do is we'll get into renewals, and we'll continue to perfect what we started here and get better at it and probably have more time to focus on the innovation side of it, which is critical obviously to growing the business as well. So I look at it as something which we would continue to get better at, which would continue to help us mitigate the overall margin pressure that we face in the business itself, but something that we feel really good about the this point.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, I wanted to ask you about the sales trends during the quarter into April, and it was pretty abrupt from quite strong to kind of weak. And I'm not going to -- I didn't see Sysco's numbers, but for the industry, it sounded like you guys outperformed t
componenttext: Bill, I wanted to ask you about the sales trends during the quarter into April, and it was pretty abrupt from quite strong to kind of weak. And I'm not going to -- I didn't see Sysco's numbers, but for the industry, it sounded like you guys outperformed that. But what you think is going on in the industry? I mean, you kind of alluded to weather because last year was easy and this March was tough. What do you think is going on in April? And I mean, do have some insight into things that are may be stabilizing or turning back up here in the later part of April, early May?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Andy, if you noticed, I really didn't talk a lot about the industry or the market because it's hard to make that call right now. While I did talk about weather, I didn't whine about weather this year, so I feel good about that. What we saw was this,
componenttext: Yes. Andy, if you noticed, I really didn't talk a lot about the industry or the market because it's hard to make that call right now. While I did talk about weather, I didn't whine about weather this year, so I feel good about that. What we saw was this, and what I alluded to in my comments, we had -- last year, if you go back and looked at the weather, it was pretty harsh in December, January and first 3 weeks in February. And it was harsh in areas where typically you don't see it -- Charlotte, Dallas, Atlanta and other places. And so we had some favorable comparisons in late December, January and February. Unfortunately, January and February are not exactly big months for us. Then if you recall last year, there's a little bit of a cabin fever impact up North, and I think people got out in March just because they needed to get out. And then March was reasonably mild and so was April, and so the camps and the clubs started to open up earlier. So we had good volume in March and April relative to the rest of the year last year, and I think we're seeing softer volume this year. What I'm trying to say here is I think weather is impacting that, I just don't know to what degree. And I think I can make a better call on that after we see May and June here because we'll be back to apples-to-apples. In terms of what I read and what I hear, it's probably not a whole lot different than you. It's -- the good news here is that the consumer sentiment is positive. It's up and down a little bit, but still positive. The sentiment of our restaurant operators is positive. It's remained positive. So I think people are generally seeing at least maintaining -- they're seeing good things and they're hopeful that it'll translate into better things. Probably the biggest positive out there right now, I would say, would be the lower fuel prices. They've come back up a little bit, but all in all, the consumer is getting a raise, if you will, at the pump. But what's not clear there at all is to what degree. It appears the consumer is paying down debt with some of that, saving some of that and spending some of that. It's not clear how much of that we're getting, perhaps some, but I don't think a lot at this point. With that said, I think to the extent that the fuel prices stayed down for an extended period of time, that will be good for our customers and I would expect that, that will help us over time. So it's a long way of saying it's hard for me to really explain what's going on in the market right now because of kind of the unusual weather comparisons as well as the impact of fuel. But I think we'll have a better read on this as we get into the summer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, I'm -- I was looking for more color. But I just wanted to clarify, following up just on what you're saying. So you're not -- I mean, in your preamble you said you expect things to get better. It sounds like it's more of a macro view of the busin
componenttext: Okay. No, I'm -- I was looking for more color. But I just wanted to clarify, following up just on what you're saying. So you're not -- I mean, in your preamble you said you expect things to get better. It sounds like it's more of a macro view of the business and -- rather than something you've seen in the last week or 2, it's a trend that's turned up?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I expect the macro to clear up is what I was trying to say. I wish I could give you more. In terms of our performance, what I alluded to in my comments, was March was softer and April softer. And -- but again, I do think some of that is the comparis
componenttext: Well, I expect the macro to clear up is what I was trying to say. I wish I could give you more. In terms of our performance, what I alluded to in my comments, was March was softer and April softer. And -- but again, I do think some of that is the comparisons, we'll see. But so let's summarize here. You got moderate inflation. You've got some FX, but let's put that aside. And you've got some softer volumes in March and April. I would expect it to pick up. I'm still very pleased with what we're doing. We're growing our volume both on the local side and the corporate side. So relative to the market, I'm pleased with where we're at there.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask Chris a question on the incentive compensation accrual you called out. It's kind of a housekeeping, but it seemed like quite a big number compared to trend and well above what the stock option alone would be. Am I -- did I that do tha
componenttext: I just wanted to ask Chris a question on the incentive compensation accrual you called out. It's kind of a housekeeping, but it seemed like quite a big number compared to trend and well above what the stock option alone would be. Am I -- did I that do that math right? And if so, could you give some explanation why the accrual was so big?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not so sure it's -- I can't respond to the last part of -- compared to what you're thinking. But the accrual itself is just what we anticipated paying out on those incentive accruals versus where we are on our objectives. And on a year-over-year
componenttext: Yes, I'm not so sure it's -- I can't respond to the last part of -- compared to what you're thinking. But the accrual itself is just what we anticipated paying out on those incentive accruals versus where we are on our objectives. And on a year-over-year basis, we're just in a much better place. So last year at this time, we were not hitting our bonus-able objectives, and so we had very little accrued. This year, we are accruing still at target because we are on pace to hit those objectives. So on a year-over-year basis, that's where you get the increase.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll -- so you're saying it's on trend with the prior quarters, there was no catch-up Q3, it's just you're on trend with a bonus accrual?
componenttext: Okay. I'll -- so you're saying it's on trend with the prior quarters, there was no catch-up Q3, it's just you're on trend with a bonus accrual?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not this year, there's -- yes, this year there's been no catch-up from quarter-to-quarter. No, last year, it bounced around because every quarter you got to look at where you are versus those objectives. And so we went through the first quarter fine, but
componenttext: Not this year, there's -- yes, this year there's been no catch-up from quarter-to-quarter. No, last year, it bounced around because every quarter you got to look at where you are versus those objectives. And so we went through the first quarter fine, but then we had start reducing the accruals Q2, Q3  because we were no longer on track to hit the target.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fine. So you were just calling on a tough comparison, and we can do the adjustment if we like. And that it is what it is. Okay.
componenttext: Fine. So you were just calling on a tough comparison, and we can do the adjustment if we like. And that it is what it is. Okay.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's really all it is, I'd like to say. I'd normally -- I try to put things on an apples-to-apples basis as much as possible. And when I look at our performance this year, especially on operating expenses, I don't like to say, "Well, we have to compare
componenttext: That's really all it is, I'd like to say. I'd normally -- I try to put things on an apples-to-apples basis as much as possible. And when I look at our performance this year, especially on operating expenses, I don't like to say, "Well, we have to compare those incentives versus a year where there were no incentives whatsoever." Now if start to pay for those incentives, and so those are real dollars and they're really going to out the door, so we don't try to, again, excuse it too much. It's when you're looking at a percentage increase, I'd like to try to do apples-to-apples. That's why I gave you the number.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Kelly Bania with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Kelly Bania with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just curious in the quarter how you think about market share and what your market share may have been? And I ask because it looks like some of the broader industry sales trends, at least for the restaurant, seemed very, very strong this quarter. So
componenttext: I was just curious in the quarter how you think about market share and what your market share may have been? And I ask because it looks like some of the broader industry sales trends, at least for the restaurant, seemed very, very strong this quarter. So I was just curious what you would think how you performed relative to the industry during the quarter?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take that one, Kelly. I -- first of all, we don't track market share quarterly. We look at it annually through different industry sources. It's primarily Technomics, and we look at the overall market in U.S. and Canada, and obviously, we look at our
componenttext: I'll take that one, Kelly. I -- first of all, we don't track market share quarterly. We look at it annually through different industry sources. It's primarily Technomics, and we look at the overall market in U.S. and Canada, and obviously, we look at our numbers. And generally, if you go back and look over the long term, Sysco has been able to grow share about 0.5 point a year, and I think we're continuing to do that. I can't really speak to this quarter on a market share because I don't have the market data. Certainly, there were some strength in our customer base, but not throughout the quarter and certainly not with all customers. So again, I was pleased at how we grew the business, but we don't really track the market share quarterly.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then if I could just follow up with one more. Just in light of McDonald's announcement to shift towards using antibiotic-free chicken on their menu. So I was just curious how Sysco is maybe positioned in terms of supply of antibiotic-free chic
componenttext: Got it. And then if I could just follow up with one more. Just in light of McDonald's announcement to shift towards using antibiotic-free chicken on their menu. So I was just curious how Sysco is maybe positioned in terms of supply of antibiotic-free chicken? Do see that as an opportunity? What kind of conversations are you having with suppliers and your customers around these products? And what could many -- what could any sales and margin implications for Sysco be if there is a broader shift from your customers to products like this?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if I could broaden the question a little bit and not make it about chicken, but just in general. That's one of the key things that we think category management will help us focus on with a broader light, which is working with our suppliers an
componenttext: Yes. I think if I could broaden the question a little bit and not make it about chicken, but just in general. That's one of the key things that we think category management will help us focus on with a broader light, which is working with our suppliers and our customers, is to better understand what the customers' needs are and how we can, as we optimize our SKUs and strategize together, do a better job of positioning product in the way that our customer want to see it, whether it's organic or local or whatever, what's important to them. So with us, it always starts the way you pose the question, which is what's important to customer, what does the customer need. And we're doing a lot of work on the customer side through the marketing department and customer loyalty initiatives to understand customer needs and then connecting that to work that we're doing with our suppliers and category management and the day-to-day provide us to better optimize our SKUs. Now it's early days and plenty of work to do there, but that's a big opportunity for us going forward. And I would also say to you, we have over the years made some good progress on the sustainability front, and I think you'll see us continue to raise the profile of that work within the company. And that group will work very closely with our customers but also with our merchandising and our marketing team. So bottom line is we do everything we can to understand what the needs of our customers are. I think we're better positioned to do that going forward, and I think we can speak more specifically about that as time goes on.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you just give a little more detail on what we could expect from the court action this week? How long will it take before we hear a decision? And if the court rules for you, is it a foregone conclusion that things would just approve -- be approved as
componenttext: Could you just give a little more detail on what we could expect from the court action this week? How long will it take before we hear a decision? And if the court rules for you, is it a foregone conclusion that things would just approve -- be approved as stated or do you still need to negotiate with the FTC? And if there's a ruling against you, how long does it take to get through the administrative hearing with the FTC?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great questions, Mark. This is new ground for all of us. I would say, as far as the timing, obviously that's in the hands of the judge in terms of how long the process takes. But the hearing starts tomorrow and the judge is given us up to 7 days, so it'll
componenttext: Great questions, Mark. This is new ground for all of us. I would say, as far as the timing, obviously that's in the hands of the judge in terms of how long the process takes. But the hearing starts tomorrow and the judge is given us up to 7 days, so it'll go through -- it's likely to go through the end of next week. Then there'll be some, as I understand it, some briefs or papers filed by each side with the judge to review, and then he'll take the time he needs to come back with a ruling. So we don't know exactly how long that is, but I would think it's closer to weeks than months. But again, that's his call. As far as what happens, as I said in my comments, if we were to prevail, then we think there's a short period of time where the FTC has an opportunity to decide whether they want appeal or not, and we would wait on that and then go from there. If they were to prevail, we'll sit down internally and then sit down with the sponsors and the owners of US Foods and charter a course from there as well. So to be determined, but that's -- those are the different ways it could play out.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe you can talk about the state of US Foods while we're waiting, because we have seen margin declines in their business through the year while we've been waiting for this deal to close?
componenttext: Okay. And maybe you can talk about the state of US Foods while we're waiting, because we have seen margin declines in their business through the year while we've been waiting for this deal to close?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I really can't comment much on US Foods. I think it goes without saying that this process has taken longer than we would have liked, and it's probably been harder on them than it has been on us. So early days, surely they lost some sales people and I thin
componenttext: I really can't comment much on US Foods. I think it goes without saying that this process has taken longer than we would have liked, and it's probably been harder on them than it has been on us. So early days, surely they lost some sales people and I think their sales were hurt. I'm not close enough to it nor should I be in terms of what their margins are right now. And obviously, they've pulled back here some on the integration planning over the last couple of months. So we'll -- I think I'll just leave it at that. I probably shouldn't be commenting on US Foods.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question comes from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question comes from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this point, just one I think easy question for you guys. SYGMA, in general, had a very strong year in fiscal '14 and has been pretty slow year-over-year to this point fiscal '15. Can you shed some light in terms of what's happened there, whether some w
componenttext: At this point, just one I think easy question for you guys. SYGMA, in general, had a very strong year in fiscal '14 and has been pretty slow year-over-year to this point fiscal '15. Can you shed some light in terms of what's happened there, whether some was by choice, maybe some wasn't by choice, and what you've -- how you feel about the overall growth of that segment over time?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I'll start and I'll let Chris jump in, too. I would say it's been a couple of years since SYGMA has had a strong year, and it's gotten a lot of attention. We have restructured there somewhat, and put Greg Keller over SYGMA full time. And Gre
componenttext: Thanks, John. I'll start and I'll let Chris jump in, too. I would say it's been a couple of years since SYGMA has had a strong year, and it's gotten a lot of attention. We have restructured there somewhat, and put Greg Keller over SYGMA full time. And Greg grew up in the SYGMA business. He's been running our national sales area up until the last several months. So he's very well-versed in the SYGMA business. He's very well connected with our customer base. He's got a lot of passion for that business. So I believe we're in good hands there from leadership. There are some things that we're working on there both in terms of how do we better position ourselves in terms of the needs of those customers and still run expenses very tight, so that's a very transaction service-oriented business. But not with a lot of touches like the Broadline, but there's no -- very little margin for error in SYGMA. So we've had to invest some money over the last year or so in terms of facilities and drivers and people like that, things like that, to strengthen the business, and that's hurt us on the bottom line. We've also had to just take a look at how well we're running the business overall. So I'd say we're in transition with SYGMA. We like the business strategically. It's a very -- that customer base or potential customer base is a big part of the overall opportunity, and it's always nice when you're sitting down with customers or prospective customers for -- to give them a choice in terms of which model they would prefer, the SYGMA model or the Broadline model. And the reality is sometimes they prefer both depending on their locations and our position. So somewhat in transition there, work to do, just strategically, still very important to the company.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Has you -- has there -- yes, hi.
componenttext: Has you -- has there -- yes, hi.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to add a couple other points. As Bill said, it's a business where expense control is incredibly important. It's a low-margin business. There have been some regulatory changes on the transportation side, drivers and work rules and things like tha
componenttext: Yes. Just to add a couple other points. As Bill said, it's a business where expense control is incredibly important. It's a low-margin business. There have been some regulatory changes on the transportation side, drivers and work rules and things like that. That while we can handle those fairly well in the Broadline, they affect SYGMA disproportionately and we're having to overcome some of those things. And as Bill said, we just -- we've got to look at the model and continue to find ways to offset increases like that. So I would echo the statement that it's in transition, we've got some work to do.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Has there been any significant account loss that's maybe been covered up by some accounts gains? And as you kind of look forward over the next couple of years, do you have any big chain opportunities to add could be coming up for bid?
componenttext: Has there been any significant account loss that's maybe been covered up by some accounts gains? And as you kind of look forward over the next couple of years, do you have any big chain opportunities to add could be coming up for bid?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's been any overly significant account loss. There's a lot -- SYGMA is no different than the rest of the business. There's a lot of pricing pressure in that business, and so we've had to deal with that as well along the way as we've loo
componenttext: I don't think there's been any overly significant account loss. There's a lot -- SYGMA is no different than the rest of the business. There's a lot of pricing pressure in that business, and so we've had to deal with that as well along the way as we've looked at expenses. But again, Greg is a very strong leader, a very strong sales guy. So I'm quite optimistic that we'll continue to find the right mix of customers and do a good job for them. But again, the way we look at SYGMA today is we want to understand what the customer is are looking for, what kind of model, what level of support, what economics are they willing to incur. And if that's the SYGMA model, then fine. If it's not, then we'll put them into Broadline. They go back and forth. And as I said, some customers utilize both models. So I think we're in good place there in terms of the direction. But from a customer standpoint, we look at it across the entire spectrum, which is what does the customer want in terms of the trade-off of service and pricing.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just go back about to the products for a second. When -- and it sounds like obviously early stages, but so far, if you been seeing any incremental demand increases from more of your customers wanting natural organic types of products. Would yo
componenttext: I wanted to just go back about to the products for a second. When -- and it sounds like obviously early stages, but so far, if you been seeing any incremental demand increases from more of your customers wanting natural organic types of products. Would you say that so far you've been able to have access to the supplies, you've been able to meet demands -- and that now as you're continuing to go through category management that, that's something that will continue to evolve. Is that fair to say at this point?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Vinny, that's what I'm trying to say. So, yes, we definitely seen that trend over the last few years. That's a trend and I have to tell you the scheme of what we do. It's not -- yes, it's not a huge amount of the business which creates part of the ch
componenttext: Hey, Vinny, that's what I'm trying to say. So, yes, we definitely seen that trend over the last few years. That's a trend and I have to tell you the scheme of what we do. It's not -- yes, it's not a huge amount of the business which creates part of the challenge where you need enough volume and enough velocity to make it work for the supplier and on the cost side and for the customer. So I would say it's like a lot of things in Sysco today. There are certainly parts of the country and certain OpCos where we do a very good job on the local side and fresh side, and then there's others not so good and that's where I see the work in merchandise and the category management, in particular, with innovation giving us a position to be more consistent. And by doing that, create more volume, which will make them more economical. So the trends have definitely been there. We're responding to them. We just -- we need to continue to get better at it. And it's a Catch 22, we need to continue to grow the volumes to make it work for everybody.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, that makes sense. Okay. And then just a quick follow-up. Inflation that you did see moderate over the quarter. Was anything kind of internally surprising to you versus your forecast from a particular category-specific standpoint? And then maybe
componenttext: All right, that makes sense. Okay. And then just a quick follow-up. Inflation that you did see moderate over the quarter. Was anything kind of internally surprising to you versus your forecast from a particular category-specific standpoint? And then maybe just additional color with your thoughts on inflation overall as we get through the rest of this year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it surprised me. I guess probably fell off faster than I thought it would be from that standpoint. It doesn't surprise me that dairy is down, for example, I mean dairy is a volatile category. But the fact that several categories are essentially flat,
componenttext: Yes, it surprised me. I guess probably fell off faster than I thought it would be from that standpoint. It doesn't surprise me that dairy is down, for example, I mean dairy is a volatile category. But the fact that several categories are essentially flat, that's probably a little surprising. And I think as far as the rest of the year, I can't -- if you're going to give me the fiscal year, I could probably look that far ahead. And I think we talked about this with John earlier. I would expect inflation to moderate somewhat more, but still expect to see some low level of inflation here this quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Erin Lash with Morningstar.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Erin Lash with Morningstar.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I apologize if this was -- if I missed this earlier. But one of the things that stood out to me in the operating expense line was that delivery costs were lower. And I wondered if you could speak to that if there was an anomaly this quarter or whether tha
componenttext: I apologize if this was -- if I missed this earlier. But one of the things that stood out to me in the operating expense line was that delivery costs were lower. And I wondered if you could speak to that if there was an anomaly this quarter or whether that's a trend that you expect to continue in light of the fact that we've been hearing that truck driver shortages continue to plague firms across a number of industries?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was mainly driven -- at least in our case, it was mainly driven by lower fuel costs, which we called out. So is the truck driver shortage abating, I would say that it's not getting any worse. We've kind of learned how to handle it, although it's n
componenttext: Yes, it was mainly driven -- at least in our case, it was mainly driven by lower fuel costs, which we called out. So is the truck driver shortage abating, I would say that it's not getting any worse. We've kind of learned how to handle it, although it's not exactly easy. But this particular quarter, we just started to see some benefit from fuel. And as you recall quarter or so ago, we talked about we'd start seeing some benefit in the back half of the year and this is it.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Erin, if I could only add, I think where we have truck -- where we have driver shortages and where it's not self-inflicted, it's generally in these areas where there's been a lot of drilling, a lot of energy. And so as that subsided somewhat, I think that
componenttext: Erin, if I could only add, I think where we have truck -- where we have driver shortages and where it's not self-inflicted, it's generally in these areas where there's been a lot of drilling, a lot of energy. And so as that subsided somewhat, I think that's actually created a little more capacity. So not all the way back there, but I think that pressure is a little less than what it was 6 or 9 months ago.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very, very helpful. And then my second question with regards to a lot of the press surrounding the avian bird flu and how you -- whether that will or to what degree you think that, that could impact your cost structure going forward?
componenttext: Okay. That's very, very helpful. And then my second question with regards to a lot of the press surrounding the avian bird flu and how you -- whether that will or to what degree you think that, that could impact your cost structure going forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really too early for me to make a call on that. I don't think, to a large extent, but it's certainly those types of things are things we monitor regularly. And -- but at this point, I'd say -- I wouldn't say it's a big issue from our cost.
componenttext: It's really too early for me to make a call on that. I don't think, to a large extent, but it's certainly those types of things are things we monitor regularly. And -- but at this point, I'd say -- I wouldn't say it's a big issue from our cost.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's affecting some of the supply as you're reading and that obviously has some impact out there. It's only if it starts affecting a very large part of the supply, not just here in the U.S. but offshore as well, that it begins to impact our ability t
componenttext: Yes, it's affecting some of the supply as you're reading and that obviously has some impact out there. It's only if it starts affecting a very large part of the supply, not just here in the U.S. but offshore as well, that it begins to impact our ability to find product and distribute it to our customers. But thus far, that's not the case, but as Bill said -- we watch this stuff. We send out crisis teams when it's important and when it becomes relevant.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that does conclude our Q&A session and our conference call for today. We appreciate your participation. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: And that does conclude our Q&A session and our conference call for today. We appreciate your participation. You may now disconnect.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sysco's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2015 Conference Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. We will begin today's call with opening remarks and introductions. I would like to turn the conference over to Neil Russell
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Sysco's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2015 Conference Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. We will begin today's call with opening remarks and introductions. I would like to turn the conference over to Neil Russell, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's Fourth Quarter and Full Year Fiscal 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Chris Kreidler, our Chief Financial Officer; and J
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's Fourth Quarter and Full Year Fiscal 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Chris Kreidler, our Chief Financial Officer; and Joel Grade, our Chief Accounting Officer.
