headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daniel, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.Before we begin,
componenttext:
Thanks, Daniel, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please note that statements made during this presentation that state the company's or management's intentions, beliefs, expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements and actual results could differ in a material manner. Additional information about factors that could cause results to differ from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the company's SEC filings. This includes, but is not limited to, risk factors contained in our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended June 26, 2015, subsequent SEC filings and in the news release issued earlier this morning. A copy of these materials can be found in the Investors section at sysco.com or via Sysco's IR app.
Non-GAAP financial measures are included in our comments today and in our presentation slides. The reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the applicable GAAP measures are included at the end of the presentation slides and can also be found in the Investors section of our website. All comments about earnings per share refer to diluted earnings per share unless otherwise noted. [Operator Instructions] 
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to our President and Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neil. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. Sysco's first quarter financial results announced this morning reflect important early progress towards achieving the 3-year financial targets we established for operating income
componenttext:
Thank you, Neil. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. Sysco's first quarter financial results announced this morning reflect important early progress towards achieving the 3-year financial targets we established for operating income and return on invested capital at our September Investor Day. The key levers for realizing these targets are accelerating local case growth, improving gross margins, leveraging our supply chain costs and reducing administrative costs. 
The quality of our overall business results for the quarter was very good, driven by strong volume growth with both our locally and corporate managed customers and sound gross margin management. However, sales growth was minimal and earnings were essentially flat due in large part to the unfavorable impact of both food cost deflation and currency translation. These 2 factors have somewhat restrained our performance for a good portion of the calendar year, and we expect that these headwinds will persist for the next few months.
Looking at broader economic and industry trends, we continue to see mixed data points with evidence of both underlying strength and optimism but also pockets of concern. Consumer confidence recently rebounded to its yearly highs in September but then fell back in October. Unemployment remains at low levels, although nonfarm employment levels have decreased steadily since May. NPD data for the 3-month period ending in August showed continued positive restaurant spend with traffic growth rebounding from the prior 3-month period. The QSR segment continues to be the main driver of positive restaurant traffic while fine dining segment also returned to a positive growth rate. Overall, restaurant traffic appears to be slightly positive. While still favorable on an absolute level, recent NRA data for September showed a decline in restaurant performance and foodservice operator confidence to levels last seen in late 2014.
Turning to our first quarter results. I'm especially pleased with performance of our U.S. Broadline business. As you know, this part of our business represents approximately 70% of Sysco's revenues and 90% of our profits. During the first quarter, our U.S. Broadline operations delivered case growth of 3.4%, including local case growth of 2%, the sixth consecutive quarter of year-over-year local case growth; gross profit dollar growth of 4.6%, nearly 2% more than our operating expense growth of 2.7%; and operating income growth of 6.4%. This performance was strong, especially after considering the impact of 1% food cost deflation in U.S. Broadline business, and drove Sysco's overall gross profit growth of more than 2% and year-over-year gross margin expansion of approximately 1/4 of 1%. 
Expense management trends continued to improve in much of our business, as reflected in the $0.01 per case cost reduction in U.S. Broadline business compared to the prior year. However, such improvement was offset by planned investment in merger-related carryover technology spend for projects that will provide key support to achieving our financial targets over the next 3 years. 
As I stated a moment ago, 2 of the key levers to achieving our 3-year financial plan are: one, accelerating our local case growth; and two, improving margins. Our results this quarter reflect good progress on doing exactly that. A few examples of the progress we've made in various areas to produce these results include our category management work, which continues to provide incremental benefits to both our customers and Sysco; improved Sysco brand penetration, especially with locally managed customers; and continued progress with our revenue management development work and early success in our pilot locations. 
In summary, our underlying business has good momentum, and we are in the right path to achieving our long-term financial and strategic objectives. 
For now, I'll turn it over to Joel for some additional details, and then I'll come back to summarize before we go to Q&A.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned, the first quarter results were of good quality, in particular for our core underlying business, the U.S. Broadline. Today, I'm going to discuss the details of the first quarter results on an adj
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. As Bill mentioned, the first quarter results were of good quality, in particular for our core underlying business, the U.S. Broadline. Today, I'm going to discuss the details of the first quarter results on an adjusted basis, which mainly excludes expenses related to the termination of the proposed merger with US Foods, as well as provide some additional pro forma comparisons on a constant currency basis. 
Our first quarter sales increased by roughly 1% despite the deflation and currency headwinds Bill noted. For some additional color on the inflation volatility we've experienced over the past year, we have transitioned from 5% inflation last year to a 0.2% deflation this year. In addition, as Bill mentioned, deflation in U.S. Broadline was even greater at about 1% for the first quarter. 
From a category perspective, center of the plate protein and dairy drove the majority of this deflation with disinflation across many other categories. To put the deflation in context, a deflationary environment has developed 2 times over the past 10 years, lasting 3 to 9 months in length when it occurred. 
As for foreign exchange, this quarter, we saw continued strength in the U.S. dollar versus the Canadian dollar and the euro. Since Canada represents the majority of our international sales, the Canadian dollar valuation was the main driver for the negative 2% impact to sales in the quarter, which is the largest impact we've experienced in recent history. When we look at our sales on a constant currency basis, they're up 3%.
Turning to other sales drivers. We reported solid case growth this quarter, including 3.4% to total and 2% local in U.S. Broadline. In addition, local and corporate-managed case growth across our total Broadline operations remained healthy. 
Despite the headwinds from foreign exchange and deflation, gross profit growth was solid at 2.3%, and gross margin expanded by 23 basis points over the prior year. Positive contributors to gross profit growth include: solid local case growth, category management and improved Sysco brand penetration. On a constant currency basis, gross profit increased by 4.3%.
Turning to expenses. Certain items during the first quarter totaled $108 million, the vast majority of which related to the termination of our merger agreement with US Foods, including $10 million that was adjusted out of operating expenses and $95 million that hit the interest expense line. As previously mentioned, this will be the final quarter to be impacted by certain items pertaining to the US Foods merger termination.
In total, our adjusted operating expense in the first quarter increased by $52 million over the prior year, mainly driven by payroll, which was impacted by both volume increases and a $9 million increase in our long-term incentive accruals. The increase in the long-term incentive accrual was related to our total shareholder return metric and was driven by the improvement in our stock price performance relative to the S&P 500. 
During the first quarter, we also started to see early signs of productivity improvements and cost reductions within our supply chain as cost per case is down approximately $0.01 in our U.S. Broadline business. On a constant currency basis, operating expenses grew by about 5%.
Adjusted operating income was down 0.5% or $3 million. However, on a constant currency basis, adjusted operating income would have been up 1.2%. 
As for our SYGMA business, we're beginning to see modest signs of improvement. For the first quarter, SYGMA sales were down 6.2% but segment operating income grew 1.4%. As we previously mentioned, we have transitioned some SYGMA business, which did pressure sales but did not negatively impact our profitability. That said, we remain focused on improving productivity, efficiency and customer profitability in SYGMA and will continue to closely monitor its progress.
Moving to other income. I want to remind you that we consolidate the results of some of the entities we control but do not have 100% ownership of. These represent investments in joint ventures, including some that are in the early investments or start-up phase. As such, our Other Income line this quarter reflects a $15 million improvement that is mostly attributable to the elimination of the non-Sysco portion of the results associated with these ventures. 
Our income tax rate for the first quarter was approximately 36% both on a GAAP and on an adjusted basis. As a reminder, the adjusted rate is on the low end of our 36% to 37% normalized rate. The GAAP rate benefited from the impact of merger-related items, which offset the strength in our U.S. business. 
Adjusted net earnings grew about 1% and benefited from both higher other income and a lower tax rate versus last year.
Adjusted earnings per share were flat for the quarter. Foreign exchange impacted earnings per share results by $0.01 per share. In addition, share count was up over 7 million shares versus the prior year, negatively impacting earnings per share by $0.01 per share as well. As a reminder, we have historically repurchased shares in the open market to offset dilution from new share issuances, but we have not done so for the past 5 quarters. We expect to resume these purchases later this year.
As you may know, we have commenced an accelerated share repurchase program, or ASR, but it had no impact on share count in this quarter. For those of you not familiar with the mechanics of the ASR, here are some details. 
Our broker borrowed 85% or approximately 32 million shares and delivered them to us on September 28, at which time our outstanding share count was reduced by that amount. Over the next several months, our broker will then acquire these shares through various mechanisms, including open market purchases. The balance of the shares covered by the accelerated share repurchase will be trued-up during settlement over the next several months.
As it pertains to cash flow, cash flow from operations for the first quarter was negative $261 million, including the cash impact of certain items, which reduced cash flow from operations by $260 million. Excluding the impact of certain items, adjusted cash flow from operations was essentially flat.
From a working capital perspective, we saw improvements in net working capital this quarter, driven by improvements in both the accounts receivable and inventory areas. This resulted in working capital using approximately $70 million less cash in the first quarter of fiscal 2016 than it did in the first quarter of fiscal 2015.
Net CapEx was $120 million for the quarter, generally flat year-over-year, mainly reflecting fleet replenishment and our investments in technology initiatives that we discussed during Investor Day.
Free cash flow for the first quarter was a negative $381 million, which includes the $260 million impact of certain items. Please keep in mind that our free cash flow is seasonal as we use more cash earlier in the fiscal year and then see larger sequential quarterly increases in free cash flow throughout the remainder of the year.
Finally, I want to remind you of the expected impact of the accelerated share repurchase on our fiscal 2016 share count and earnings per share. On our last earnings call, we said that we anticipate a benefit of approximately $0.03 to $0.04 of diluted earnings per share in fiscal 2016, driven by a 4% to 5% reduction in average shares outstanding, partially offset by higher interest expense and new debt issuance. Now that we have begun execution of this plan, we still maintain this guidance.
I'll now turn it back to Bill for his closing remarks.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joel. In summary, I am encouraged by the quality of our first quarter results and, in particular, with performance of our U.S. Broadline business. We are now experiencing consistent improvement in our local volume growth trends and gross margin ma
componenttext:
Thanks, Joel. In summary, I am encouraged by the quality of our first quarter results and, in particular, with performance of our U.S. Broadline business. We are now experiencing consistent improvement in our local volume growth trends and gross margin management in this all-important part of our business as a result of improved execution of several commercial initiatives implemented over the past few years. 
Expense management trends have improved of late, and we are also making good strides in developing and refining action plans to accelerate additional cost improvement benefits both in our supply chain and administrative areas of Sysco. We will provide regular updates on an ongoing basis in achieving our targeted results for improving our customers' experience, enhancing associate engagement and meeting our 2018 financial goals for operating income and return on invested capital. 
And with that, operator, we'll now take questions.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from John Heinbockel from Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from John Heinbockel from Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, so 2 things. Number one, what's the update on the competitive pricing environment? I know it did -- I think it had heated up a little bit going back a couple of months, but yet I would think as we go forward here and things normalize, that we would
componenttext: Bill, so 2 things. Number one, what's the update on the competitive pricing environment? I know it did -- I think it had heated up a little bit going back a couple of months, but yet I would think as we go forward here and things normalize, that we would see that come down quite a bit. And then secondly, if I look at your U.S. Broadline EBIT up 6.4%, is there any way to kind of parse through what that might be in a more normal inflation environment? Would it be the same but have different components? Or would it be different?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the competitive environment, I would say pretty much what we've been saying, that the competitive environment remains very acute, comes in all forms of competitors, large, small, local regional, et cetera, national, that kind of thing. As far as
componenttext: Okay. On the competitive environment, I would say pretty much what we've been saying, that the competitive environment remains very acute, comes in all forms of competitors, large, small, local regional, et cetera, national, that kind of thing. As far as I think what you're getting at, some of our larger competitors, they're on different stages right now in terms of where they are in developing and driving out their strategic plans and that type of thing. So I would say generally, John, the competitive environment remains very competitive but reasonably rational. And yet at the same time, I would tell you in any given day in any given market, there's probably some volatility and probably some inconsistencies with what I'm telling you there. But I don't think a big change from when we were -- talked a few months ago. As far as the U.S. Broadline is concerned, it's a good question. I would say to you -- let me -- without the deflation in that -- honestly, I would just tell you it would have been much better or at least somewhat better without the deflation. We had good gross profit growth, as I said, even with deflation, very good case growth and we managed the margins well. We've got work to do, John. So we still have work to do on the expense side here in all parts of our business, and we're beginning to make some strides there. But I would say without the deflation, U.S. Broadline would have been -- probably had somewhat of a stronger performance.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up to that, the -- when you think about your long-term targets, I mean, it strikes me that with all you're doing on revenue management and kind of where you've been, gross margin -- and I guess this was hit on a little bit during
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up to that, the -- when you think about your long-term targets, I mean, it strikes me that with all you're doing on revenue management and kind of where you've been, gross margin -- and I guess this was hit on a little bit during the Analyst Day, but gross could surprise to the upside. The other piece, right, is in holding SG&A growth to 3%. It seems a little tough if you're seeing some case growth. At the end of the day, do you -- I mean, the 1% spread, that's the goal. Do you think it's pretty likely that, that spread holds, but it's possible that we see both gross profit and SG&A growing some -- a fair bit faster than that? Or that seems unlikely?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it just depends. I mean, right now, deflation is somewhat of a headwind as it relates to the gross profit growth. But -- and there's a lot of things, as you know, John, that impact margin, from macro events to mix and that type of thing. I t
componenttext: Well, I think it just depends. I mean, right now, deflation is somewhat of a headwind as it relates to the gross profit growth. But -- and there's a lot of things, as you know, John, that impact margin, from macro events to mix and that type of thing. I think what I'm conveying to you today is a lot of these initiatives that we've taken on over the last 2 or 3 years are beginning to bear fruit, whether it's how we manage our sales force, rolling out CatMan, continue to work on the brand in the right way in conjunction with CatMan and early days of revenue management, which manifests itself in a lot of different ways. So I'm feeling good about our ability to manage margin. I think what you heard us say at the Analyst Day or the Investor Day, well, there's things we don't control. So right now, our GP was up -- it was up. Well, it was up overall. It was up nicely in U.S. Broadline. But I would -- we're not at that spread right now overall, so I would say to you the plan here is to get back to that spread of at least 1% between gross profit dollar growth and expense growth. And what we need to do to do that, we need to maintain the momentum we've done on local case growth, we've got to continue to manage those gross margins well and we do need to get our expense increases to a lower level.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Meredith Adler from Barclays.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Meredith Adler from Barclays.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if there were any particular initiatives you're using to drive the locally managed case growth. And then I have one other quick question.
componenttext: I was wondering if there were any particular initiatives you're using to drive the locally managed case growth. And then I have one other quick question.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's a lot of things, Meredith. If you recall at the Investor Day, in combination -- well, we took you through a lot of different strategies and processes that we're doing. I would say under Tom's leadership, there's some basic things. There's a v
componenttext: I think it's a lot of things, Meredith. If you recall at the Investor Day, in combination -- well, we took you through a lot of different strategies and processes that we're doing. I would say under Tom's leadership, there's some basic things. There's a very tight cadence of meetings between him and his market leadership and the field, weekly, monthly, quarterly, that type of thing. So we've got good continuity there. Some of the segmentation work that Tom spoke to both in terms of customer segmentation, product category opportunities, those are looking for opportunities within every cell that we operate in, whether it's geographically, across customer segments. We talked about Hispanic. We talked about potentially more opportunity in the local fresh area, that type of thing but also just basic things where you sit down as a management team, whether it's locally or through the CatMan group, and look at categories that you may be underpenetrated in. So it's -- we've got good alignment around good basic business principles, good connectivity between what we're doing here at corporate and to the market, and then, obviously, where it all happens in the field. And we also think CatMan continues to help. It's going to -- as it matures in terms of some of the sourcing aspects of it, it's going to help us, I think, create more momentum and innovation and, over time, optimizing our SKU count as we strike the right balance between reducing SKUs where we have redundancies but also broadening our SKUs for some of the items that may be new or maybe don't move quite as fast but are particularly important to customers. So it's -- a lot of it's process and a lot of it's, again, going back to these commercial issues that we've been developing and employing here over the last 2 or 3 years.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So is it -- are these changes or, would you say, just getting some things that you've started working on sort of coming to fruition?
componenttext: So is it -- are these changes or, would you say, just getting some things that you've started working on sort of coming to fruition?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's both. I mean, so if you go back -- and so the -- we do some of the sales tools and that type of thing we've been using for 3 years or more, and they're beginning to mature. CatMan has been out there for 2 or 3 years, but the revenue management work i
componenttext: It's both. I mean, so if you go back -- and so the -- we do some of the sales tools and that type of thing we've been using for 3 years or more, and they're beginning to mature. CatMan has been out there for 2 or 3 years, but the revenue management work is really just beginning. And so we're in various stages on all of these. I think probably the biggest thing right now outside of that, Meredith, is just I just feel we have really good alignment right now across that whole triangle we took you through between facing up at -- where it matters most, which is at the customer level, supporting that in the market and then continuing to develop good tools here but field-ready tools, and we're getting better at that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then my -- just my quick sort of follow-up question is, I noticed again this quarter you had added back some severance costs, and I was wondering, is there -- was there some kind of a severance program or a layoff program somewhere in the company that
componenttext: And then my -- just my quick sort of follow-up question is, I noticed again this quarter you had added back some severance costs, and I was wondering, is there -- was there some kind of a severance program or a layoff program somewhere in the company that you hadn't specifically called out?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have some ongoing opportunities there. I'll let Joel speak.
componenttext: We have some ongoing opportunities there. I'll let Joel speak.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Meredith, this is Joel. I'd call that more on the -- just on a normal basis. There's nothing significant that happened there.
componenttext: Yes, Meredith, this is Joel. I'd call that more on the -- just on a normal basis. There's nothing significant that happened there.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So they're added back for what reason if they're ongoing?
componenttext: So they're added back for what reason if they're ongoing?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: They're added back because I think as we go through this transformation, Meredith, there's going to be some peaks and valleys on that line. And right now, we're in a little bit of a valley, which is nice, but it's -- again, we're transforming here a $45 b
componenttext: They're added back because I think as we go through this transformation, Meredith, there's going to be some peaks and valleys on that line. And right now, we're in a little bit of a valley, which is nice, but it's -- again, we're transforming here a $45 billion, $50 billion company that's been in business for 40 years. So we'll continue to optimize our workforce.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next, from Jefferies we have Mark Wiltamuth.
componenttext: And next, from Jefferies we have Mark Wiltamuth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I Wanted to just kind of find out where some of the weakness is here because if your Broadline business is 90% of profits, and that was up 6.4%, and SYGMA was actually modestly profitable, where is the big missing link here to get you down to a flat opera
componenttext: I Wanted to just kind of find out where some of the weakness is here because if your Broadline business is 90% of profits, and that was up 6.4%, and SYGMA was actually modestly profitable, where is the big missing link here to get you down to a flat operating income performance? Are there some sizable international losses or just noncore businesses that are weaker?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say most of our businesses performs very well. There's a couple that didn't. I wouldn't say those are overly material to your question. The -- as I mentioned in my comments, we've got some planned expense increases at corporate, largely in the bus
componenttext: I would say most of our businesses performs very well. There's a couple that didn't. I wouldn't say those are overly material to your question. The -- as I mentioned in my comments, we've got some planned expense increases at corporate, largely in the business technology area. We talked about this sort of the last couple of calls. We had some projects that were going down the road in anticipation of US Foods merger, had some opportunities here that we think are very compelling, especially on the customer-facing side of the business. And so we've continued down with those, and that's created, on a year-over-year basis, a bigger delta on the expense side of corporate. And Joel mentioned we took a hit on some long-term incentives here because of the stock performance. So it's a little bit everything, but it's mostly corporate, some of which is planned, some of which was just kind of the mark-to-market, if you will, of the LTI.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: As well as the foreign exchange impact, just as a reminder.
componenttext: As well as the foreign exchange impact, just as a reminder.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just over time, is there going to be some normalization of the corporate expenses now that you're kind of not pursuing US Foods? And then maybe can you give us the arc of what that spending looks like?
componenttext: Okay. And just over time, is there going to be some normalization of the corporate expenses now that you're kind of not pursuing US Foods? And then maybe can you give us the arc of what that spending looks like?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would answer that in the context of all expenses. And so again, we're -- as we continue to evolve here as a company, we -- there's certainly a corporate group and there's markets and OpCos. But we look at optimizing spend throughout. And so if you
componenttext: Yes, I would answer that in the context of all expenses. And so again, we're -- as we continue to evolve here as a company, we -- there's certainly a corporate group and there's markets and OpCos. But we look at optimizing spend throughout. And so if you go back to those 4 levers I talked about, the last 2 levers are really about optimizing our expense management. And so there's significant opportunity that we believe both on the supply chain side as well as on the administrative side, and we're working through that now. You saw some of it in the supply chain side this quarter. We had a pretty good quarter there. And on the administrative side, those are more thoughtful processes that we need to go through, and we'll communicate those to you over the next few months.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And following, we have Edward Kelly from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And following, we have Edward Kelly from Credit Suisse.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, just a follow-up on the cost control side. Your expense growth up in the 3% range. And clearly, just looking at the way that you reported U.S. Broadline performance, there were some expenses in here that sound like over time should eventually kind o
componenttext: Bill, just a follow-up on the cost control side. Your expense growth up in the 3% range. And clearly, just looking at the way that you reported U.S. Broadline performance, there were some expenses in here that sound like over time should eventually kind of roll off. How should we think about SG&A growth over the next few quarters? And then over time, is there an ability to grow SG&A at a slower rate than what it's growing at today? Or the case growth was pretty good. You had 3% SG&A growth, but there's a lot of corporate spend in there. If you could sort of help us put it all together in terms of how we should be thinking about this.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Ed. The way I would be thinking about both the way we laid out our 3-year goals as well as the way this year's plan is targeted is in that 3-year plan, we said it wouldn't be linear. This year is not going to be linear and there's a -- there'
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Ed. The way I would be thinking about both the way we laid out our 3-year goals as well as the way this year's plan is targeted is in that 3-year plan, we said it wouldn't be linear. This year is not going to be linear and there's a -- there's less of a trajectory, if you will, on the operating income in the first year than there is in year 2 and year 3. The short answer to your question is yes, I think as we get into breaking down those costs, especially -- I don't really want to call them SG&A, I'm just going to call them administrative costs regardless of what part of the business they're in, whether they're locally or corporate or in between and whether they're purely admin or just administrative in nature. You should expect to see those numbers -- that growth to -- that curve to become more shallow as we go forward. What I would say on the earlier question was we did plan in some meaningful technology spend this year to finish off some projects that we had started with the merger that are very compelling from a customer-facing standpoint but also had significant cost. And so that's driving a lot of that expense delta here right now. So I was pleased with the overall cost per piece in the business. The corporate departments actually manage their expenses fine. We have the technology spend and we had this other issue here on the incentive accruals. So short answer to your question is it will begin to grow at a slower rate, and that's probably going to take us another couple of quarters to give you some visibility on that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. But then after that, sort of like the true performance of Broadline, which is really what you're trying to communicate here, should be more evident?
componenttext: Okay. But then after that, sort of like the true performance of Broadline, which is really what you're trying to communicate here, should be more evident?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a follow-up for you here. It's been a few months, I guess, at least since China has become more involved with the company. And at the Analyst Day, you had kind of suggested that there hadn't really been too much, I guess, influence y
componenttext: Got it. And then just a follow-up for you here. It's been a few months, I guess, at least since China has become more involved with the company. And at the Analyst Day, you had kind of suggested that there hadn't really been too much, I guess, influence yet. I was just curious as to whether you can provide some update in terms of the impact they're having on your business and the way you think about things strategically, if at all yet.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Well, I think that the Analyst Day, they had just gotten on the board, I think, within a week or 2 of that or 2 or 3 weeks at least of that day. So I won't speak for them, but they've been doing -- continuing to do their work. So they've pulled
componenttext: Yes, sure. Well, I think that the Analyst Day, they had just gotten on the board, I think, within a week or 2 of that or 2 or 3 weeks at least of that day. So I won't speak for them, but they've been doing -- continuing to do their work. So they've pulled a lot of data and they're looking at our information. They're visiting facilities, they're meeting with our management team, that type of thing. Their first real board meeting is our board meeting in November. And I'm sure we'll, at that point between now and then and then after that, get better clarity on their thoughts in more detail and the breadth of their thoughts. And as board members, we'll work through it appropriately.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: And following, we have Karen Short from Deutsche Bank.

componenttext: I had just 2 housekeeping questions and a bigger picture question. Do you -- can you give us the case volume growth, including SYGMA? That used to be a metric that you gave us. Wondering if you could give that again.

componenttext: We can get that for you, Karen. The only reason we don't show that anymore is because obviously, we're going through some transition with SYGMA, so we don't think it's overly reflective of what's really going on in the company. But if we can't give it to you on the call, we'll come back to you.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Come back. And the second housekeeping I just had is, I don't -- do you have the private label penetration as a percent of sales at the local level? Or is it fairly consistent with the Broadline number that you have in your press release? Or is it lower o
componenttext: Come back. And the second housekeeping I just had is, I don't -- do you have the private label penetration as a percent of sales at the local level? Or is it fairly consistent with the Broadline number that you have in your press release? Or is it lower or higher?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We track it that way. But because you have customers that transition back and forth, generally they go one way into pure street to local contract to corporate managed, we think looking at it in total is better. So I would say generally, we're seeing compa
componenttext: We track it that way. But because you have customers that transition back and forth, generally they go one way into pure street to local contract to corporate managed, we think looking at it in total is better. So I would say generally, we're seeing comparable growth at the local business as well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just a bigger picture question. I guess obviously, you've told us a lot about how you plan to focus on local customers, and it obviously sounds like the right strategy. But is there anything about Sysco specifically that gives you a
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just a bigger picture question. I guess obviously, you've told us a lot about how you plan to focus on local customers, and it obviously sounds like the right strategy. But is there anything about Sysco specifically that gives you a competitive advantage in capturing, entertaining the customer? And I'm -- I guess I'm asking because it's obviously a higher-margin customer, so that strategically makes sense. But, I mean, it just makes sense that all your competitors are going to be doing the same thing. So what is it about Sysco that makes you more attractive as a supplier or afford you better retention? Any color on that would be great.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Karen, just -- I didn't understand it. Can you just restate the first part of your question? So what is it about Sysco that you're asking?
componenttext: Karen, just -- I didn't understand it. Can you just restate the first part of your question? So what is it about Sysco that you're asking?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it just seems obvious that if everyone should be going after the higher-margin customer, which is the local customer, so all your competitors are doing the same thing, I would assume. So is there anything specifically about Sysco that would h
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it just seems obvious that if everyone should be going after the higher-margin customer, which is the local customer, so all your competitors are doing the same thing, I would assume. So is there anything specifically about Sysco that would help you retain or capture a customer or have better success at capturing that customer and retaining them versus your competitors?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I think there's a lot of things. I mean, I think it's not like we just started doing that, okay? We've been doing it for 45 years. We do -- half of that $50 billion we do, roughly half of that is with local or street, a little bit more if you
componenttext: Sure. Well, I think there's a lot of things. I mean, I think it's not like we just started doing that, okay? We've been doing it for 45 years. We do -- half of that $50 billion we do, roughly half of that is with local or street, a little bit more if you go to local. So it's the DNA of the company. It's in our -- it's woven into the fabric of this company. It's how we've grown to where we are today. I think the point we made at Investor Day is with some of the challenges we've had in the macro environment and the acute -- the increased competition that came from 2009 simultaneously with us driving out a heck of a lot of transformational change, we struggled over the last few years until last year to drive the local case growth. So it's nothing new. It's just something we haven't done as well as we would have liked over the last few years, and there's reasons for that. So in terms of why Sysco, I think it starts with our sales force. We've got 7,000 market associates across the country. Our structure that we continue to find ways to optimize, but one of the reasons we remain very local is because, as I've said many times, about 2/3 of our revenue strength comes from customers whose decision makers are domiciled within 100, 150 miles of that operating company. So that creates a need not just for local sales representation for local leadership with our presidents and senior teams there. So I think our geographic footprint, the talent of our operating teams, the experience and the breadth of our sales force, all these new things that we've been talking about earlier on the call on the commercial initiative side from CatMan to RevMan to segmentation, listening to our customers in a much more effective way through -- over the last 3 or 4 years that have led to increased loyalty, the fact that we had the courage to take on transforming this company at a time -- key inflection point in our country and in our industry, we're one of the few people in our industry that has taken on this kind of change. So I think the fact that we're forward looking and we've got great people and we've got great strategy, I think those are all reasons why we should continue to have a lot of success.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Karen, it's Joel. Just the total Broadline plus SYGMA case growth was 2.4% for the quarter as a  follow-up.
componenttext: And Karen, it's Joel. Just the total Broadline plus SYGMA case growth was 2.4% for the quarter as a  follow-up.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Vincent Sinisi from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to inflation and deflation, what you're seeing on a category basis. I know that the slight deflation, you called out center of the plate and dairy primarily. But how was that relative to your internal expectations for this quarter?
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to inflation and deflation, what you're seeing on a category basis. I know that the slight deflation, you called out center of the plate and dairy primarily. But how was that relative to your internal expectations for this quarter? And then has anything more recently changed? I know that you said kind of for the next few months. Just maybe a little bit more color on how you see the inflation-deflation outlook this year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vinny, I'll start and then I'll let Joel kind of tighten it up a little bit. I would say what's different is there was a little more deflation than maybe what we would have expected 3 months ago when we were on this call on U.S. Broadline, and it app
componenttext: Yes, Vinny, I'll start and then I'll let Joel kind of tighten it up a little bit. I would say what's different is there was a little more deflation than maybe what we would have expected 3 months ago when we were on this call on U.S. Broadline, and it appears to be lasting longer. And so I would tell you it's probably going to get a little worse before it gets better. We're seeing that early part of this quarter, and I think that could be with us at least into the third quarter. Joel?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I guess the only thing I'll just remind you of, again, we certainly think about inflation in our business as by category. And so again, many of the categories we have are relatively flat, and so some of the volatility we're seeing really is in a
componenttext: Yes. And I guess the only thing I'll just remind you of, again, we certainly think about inflation in our business as by category. And so again, many of the categories we have are relatively flat, and so some of the volatility we're seeing really is in a couple of categories. So it's a little bit hard to see where that's headed. But again, and as Bill mentioned, it certainly feels like it's going to go a bit -- a little bit worse before it gets better as we move throughout the rest of this year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a quick follow-up, at your Analyst Day, you had made a quick question of you doing some work with Kroger and some of its fresh products. I know that obviously, that's probably pretty small at this point. But maybe just any kind of early reads
componenttext: Okay. And as a quick follow-up, at your Analyst Day, you had made a quick question of you doing some work with Kroger and some of its fresh products. I know that obviously, that's probably pretty small at this point. But maybe just any kind of early reads or color on the scope and if that overall initiative is something that you could see expanding going forward.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Vinny, I think what we said was we're just beginning to do that work and it's just been a few weeks. So, so far so good. Early days, but we're very excited about the opportunity.
componenttext: Vinny, I think what we said was we're just beginning to do that work and it's just been a few weeks. So, so far so good. Early days, but we're very excited about the opportunity.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: And following, we have Andrew Wolf from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the 2% local case growth, do you have a feel for how you had split that between what the market's giving you in terms of growth maybe with independents having positive same-store sales, if they are, versus how much you might be taking?
componenttext: On the 2% local case growth, do you have a feel for how you had split that between what the market's giving you in terms of growth maybe with independents having positive same-store sales, if they are, versus how much you might be taking?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we - that'd be difficult, Andy. I -- certainly, as I said at the Investor Day, the market environment even today is kind of as it's -- there's not a lot of consistency to it, but I think when you look at it in the context of where we were 5 or 6 years
componenttext: No, we - that'd be difficult, Andy. I -- certainly, as I said at the Investor Day, the market environment even today is kind of as it's -- there's not a lot of consistency to it, but I think when you look at it in the context of where we were 5 or 6 years ago, even 2 or 3 years ago, we're in a better market environment. So I'm sure that's helping everybody to some degree, but I certainly would think that we're taking share with 2% growth. We update those numbers about once a year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the way I would think about that, again it's joint ventures that are reported on a consolidation method. So if you look at each one of the lines, from sales, gross profit, expenses, operating income, up above the operating income line, they're consol
componenttext: Yes, the way I would think about that, again it's joint ventures that are reported on a consolidation method. So if you look at each one of the lines, from sales, gross profit, expenses, operating income, up above the operating income line, they're consolidated. And then below the line, the portion of that, so I'll say the non-Sysco, the part that we don't own, is backed out. So if you net out all of it between the above the line and below the line, it's a relatively small number. But that's the way the accounting works. And that's why that part of it shows up in other income. I hope that helps.  Now the -- yes, well, there's a non-majority ownership, in other words. And then so the whole thing is reported up above and then the minority, the part that we don't own is backed out down below.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had a question about some of the cost cutting opportunities. It seemed like at your investor conference, one of the major themes was you've got a very growth-oriented outlook. And I understand that it's very early in your 3-year planning process an
componenttext: I just had a question about some of the cost cutting opportunities. It seemed like at your investor conference, one of the major themes was you've got a very growth-oriented outlook. And I understand that it's very early in your 3-year planning process and that it's not a linear runway, but just from a cost-cutting perspective, where do you see the addressable opportunity? And what are some of the major buckets. If you can talk about that. And then as a related question, like could you significantly reduce some of the variable costs like payroll costs without hurting your sales? So to what extent is that an issue in relation to your 3-year outlook?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ajay, I think what we certainly attempted to convey at the Investor Day was we need to continue to grow. We believe we can grow profitably and take share in the right way, but it needs to be more targeted growth than what we've seen over the past --
componenttext: Yes, Ajay, I think what we certainly attempted to convey at the Investor Day was we need to continue to grow. We believe we can grow profitably and take share in the right way, but it needs to be more targeted growth than what we've seen over the past -- we need a little more balance between the corporate-managed growth and the local growth. And it's not that we don't want corporate-managed growth. We do. We just need to see a little bit more balance there. So I think on the cost cutting, the way I actually look at it in terms of running a business, we'll go to your last question, which is to cut costs. There's no trophies for cutting cost all right? So the -- to cut costs and to do it in a way where you go and anticipate what the downside would be would be somewhat foolish on our part. And that's why we're taking some time here on the administrative cost side to go through and look at the work, look at the prioritization of the work, look at the sequencing of the work, look at the structure, look at how much we still need to do on the technology side, for example, to continue to be out there in front with our customers to be responsive to their needs. So what we're doing right now is prioritizing all of that in a way that we need to put it together in a fiscally responsible way. And then we'll bring it back to you and to our customer base and to our associates in the most balanced way that we can and the least risky way that we can. So certainly, if we were to go out and cut back dramatically on customer-facing technology support or customer-facing associates, that wouldn't be a very smart way to proceed here. So we're proceeding -- we see opportunities, as I said multiple times now, in all parts of the business. Where you're seeing focused primarily right now is on supply chain and the administrative side. And I think over the next couple of quarters, we'll be able to give you more visibility to that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take Kelly Bania from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll take Kelly Bania from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just curious, as you look at your case growth, either local or in total, if you could talk about any of the trends that you're seeing there, either product types or categories that are really working well. And I guess somewhat related to that, many
componenttext: I was just curious, as you look at your case growth, either local or in total, if you could talk about any of the trends that you're seeing there, either product types or categories that are really working well. And I guess somewhat related to that, many a restaurant and QSRs have recently announced plans to transition their proteins towards antibiotic free, and I was just curious if you could talk about how you're positioned against that trend with both your customers and suppliers.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kelly, it's Bill. I think on the first part of the question, if you go back and look over the last 2 or 3 years and look where our growth has come at, I think we've done a really nice job in building out the center of the plate. So in particular, those pr
componenttext: Kelly, it's Bill. I think on the first part of the question, if you go back and look over the last 2 or 3 years and look where our growth has come at, I think we've done a really nice job in building out the center of the plate. So in particular, those protein items that you were talking about, whether it's meat, seafood, poultry and even the produce and dairy along the way, so continue to, I think, see good opportunity there. A lot of it is fresh. Not all of it, though. I think it's still a little early to tell. We certainly acknowledge and are reacting and trying to be as proactive as possible in terms of some of the accelerating trends as it relates to the local and organic and that type of thing as well as ethnic opportunities. I would tell you those are real trends and meaningful and very important to our customers. I don't know that I can tell you today that, that's really driving substantial dollars, but it certainly is an area where we need to be going forward. I think your second question, I'll probably need to do a little more work on. I think we've had some good initiatives going on both on the merchandising side of our business, in particular projection of CatMan and the sustainability area, and we're putting more resources into those. So let us come back to you on that in terms of how that winds up going forward.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just on deflation. I think last year when inflation was running quite a bit higher, there was some difficulty in passing all those on. Could you just talk about how deflation impacted your gross margin in the quarter? Was there an
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just on deflation. I think last year when inflation was running quite a bit higher, there was some difficulty in passing all those on. Could you just talk about how deflation impacted your gross margin in the quarter? Was there any lag in passing that along? Was that helpful to the gross margin? Or I guess it depends on the category, but any color you can provide there.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, I get this question a lot, and I'm going to stay consistent with what I've always said. Our -- the ideal place for us to be would be to have 2 or 3 points of inflation across every category. I mean, that's as good as it gets. I've never seen it
componenttext: Yes. Yes, I get this question a lot, and I'm going to stay consistent with what I've always said. Our -- the ideal place for us to be would be to have 2 or 3 points of inflation across every category. I mean, that's as good as it gets. I've never seen it in 27 years of doing this. But that would be very good. And why is that? That's because history tells you and the data tells you that most of our customers are able to pass that type of increase along in a reasonably manageable way and a way that works for their business. So 2 to 3 overall would be fine. Now when it gets up over that 4%, 5%, 6%, that's not good for our customers, and that's -- when it starts off, so make it difficult for us to pass that much along on a timely basis. Now deflation would be the least attractive of all of those. It probably does -- it certainly does help your margins to some extent in terms of the percentage. But, as we all understand, you're taking fewer dollars to the bank to pay bills, so it puts a lot of pressure on your expenses along the way. So deflation, we haven't seen a lot of it over the -- we did some work on this, I think, over the last decade. And we've only had deflation a couple of times, and I think it's ranged from, in one instance, a quarter or so; in another instance, maybe 2, 3 quarters. So we think we'll probably be on the lower end of that this time around. But it's a challenging environment. I will tell you I think we've -- I think we're doing a good job striking the right balance in terms of managing that down in a way that works for the customer but still is working for us, and I think you saw that in the numbers this quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one other question. You talked in the beginning about some of the economic factors being somewhat mixed overall. But then you mentioned, I think, that there was a pretty sharp pullback in confidence among restaurant operators. And I
componenttext: Got it. And then just one other question. You talked in the beginning about some of the economic factors being somewhat mixed overall. But then you mentioned, I think, that there was a pretty sharp pullback in confidence among restaurant operators. And I was just curious if you had any color on what you think drove that or what maybe you're hearing from your customers about why that would be.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what we said on the restaurant part of it was that it went back to kind of where we were about 1 year ago. So, I mean, it's still much improved over the last 3 or 4 years. They're -- both in consumer confidence and on those NRA statistics, we
componenttext: Yes, I think what we said on the restaurant part of it was that it went back to kind of where we were about 1 year ago. So, I mean, it's still much improved over the last 3 or 4 years. They're -- both in consumer confidence and on those NRA statistics, we're almost back to where we were in 2009. Again, that's 2009, and so you need to put in some context. It's hard to pinpoint. I -- look, the restaurant operators, they're people like all of us. So I think when you see a stock market going up and down with that kind of volatility, it makes people nervous. And that could be part of it. It's -- what we're really telling you is there didn't seem to be any discernible medium-term trend. It's up for a quarter or 2, and then it's down and then back up again. So overall, in the context of looking back 2, 3, 4 years, it's much better. It's just -- it's hard to see a pattern here.

componenttext: Now I haven't seen a lot of October data yet, John, and I -- our trends are pretty similar to what we saw in the first quarter. It's tough for us week to week how they fall in different weeks or days and that kind of thing, but I would just tell you sitting here we're -- I can't tell you there's been any big shift in demand or anything like that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, obviously, the restaurant industry gets the opposite of what it was a couple of years ago, where there was no labor inflation and there was significant commodity inflation. So as you think about the pricing environment, as you can pass
componenttext: And then secondly, obviously, the restaurant industry gets the opposite of what it was a couple of years ago, where there was no labor inflation and there was significant commodity inflation. So as you think about the pricing environment, as you can pass on pricing to your restaurant customers as you're own labor costs are higher, do you think that we're in an environment that could be modestly better from a pricing environment relative to what we've seen before?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, could be what?
componenttext: I'm sorry, could be what?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are we in an environment where you can pass on more pricing to restaurant customers than you could before? I mean, I understand that you were -- the pricing of your products coming in through your back door is deflationary. But is this a potentially bette
componenttext: Are we in an environment where you can pass on more pricing to restaurant customers than you could before? I mean, I understand that you were -- the pricing of your products coming in through your back door is deflationary. But is this a potentially better pricing environment from Sysco and to the restaurant customers as restaurant customers are seeing [indiscernible] deflation?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know about that. I think what we're -- what you're hearing from us as we begin to develop a real revenue management process is, there's opportunities for us with analytics in terms of the segmentation we're doing both across product categorie
componenttext: Yes, I don't know about that. I think what we're -- what you're hearing from us as we begin to develop a real revenue management process is, there's opportunities for us with analytics in terms of the segmentation we're doing both across product categories as well as customers. There's opportunities for us to be smarter and more consistent and to be more on the market in terms of what's important to our customers. So I think that's the bigger opportunity. I was with a customer the other day, and your point on labor, it's the biggest thing we hear today from every customer we talk to. There's just a -- and you see it in the press, there's a labor shortage our there. They're having to adjust their cost structure accordingly. And I think that actually does the opposite of your question. It puts a little more pressure on some pricing because they're always looking for opportunities to manage their cost. But overall, I'd say it's -- it's not a bad environment right now from a pricing standpoint other than the deflation aspect of it.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
